div.head: To his Grace the Duke of ORMOND, Lord Steward of His Majesties Houshold, Chancellor of the Vniversity of Oxford.
div.p: THis Comedy was Written by the Sacred Command of our late most Excellent King, of ever blessed and beloved Memory. I had the great good Fortune to please Him often at His Court in my Masque, on the Stage of Tragedies and Comedies, and so to advance my self in His good opinion; an Honour may render a wiser Man than I vain; for I believe he had more equals in extent of Dominions than of Understanding. The greatest pleasure he had from the Stage was in Comedy, and he often Commanded me to Write it, and lately gave me a Spanish Play called No Puedeser: Or, It cannot Be. out of which I took part o' the Name, and design o' this. I received the Employment as a great Honour, because it was difficult; requiring no ordinary skill and pains to build a little Shallop, sit only for the Spanish South Seas, into an English Ship Royal; but I believe my self able for the Work, because he thought so, who understood me and all Men, better than I only knew my self, encourag'd by Royal judgment that never was mistaken, I have attained a success I never should have met with, had I only followed my own feeble Genius, which often deceives me. That I may enjoy the little fortune I have got with the better reputation, and not ramble the World like a blind Author, observing none but my self, I make this humble Application to your Grace. I am sure all the World will approve my choice. I cannot be guilty of Flattery if I would; nor slander Wit (if I had any) by fulsome and wanton Paintings. Here will be no Tryal of skill how I can praise, Nature has done it to my Hands, and devis'd and expos'd finer Ideas, than I am able to Translate. A gracefulness of Person, excellence of Understanding, largeness of Heart, a Loyalty, Gallantry, Integrity, Humility, and many Qualities above my description. Fortune also has been more wise than usual, She frequently honours and enriches others to her own disgrace— but here She shares in the Praise, and Commends her own Wisdome, in what She bestows on your Grace. She has advanc'd Honour in Advancing you, Titles, Greatness and Command may be proved, they have attained you. Wealth has a value in your Hands, 'Tis no vile pardon, poor flatterer, servile Lacquey, wretched Prisoner; but excellent Minister of a just wise and liberal Prince. Shou'd I mention all the Qualities, that have long gained you the highest Honours from Prince and People, I should rather seem to describe a Province than a Man; for what single Province can afford what are at once in your Grace, a General, a Statesman, Courtier, and all in perfection; and which is rare in such company, a Martyr. What has your Grace both done and suffered, for our Religion, Laws, Liberties and Honour? And not only in the former times of Rebellion, but the latter of Confusion? When the pretended Protestants of the times, out of their Zeal against all Popish Doctrines, abhorring you for adhering to good Works.

As an English-man, I am bound in justice, to pay you all the Honours I can. You have been an Ornament, and support to the Crown and Church of England, both in your Person and Posterity. Many great Men no doubt have sprung from your example, but none equalling those descended from your self. The late brave Earl of Ossery, advanced the Honour of our Nation, both by Sea and Land. 'Tis hard to say in which Element he made us most renown'd, and for which vertue. He was no more to be vanquished by falshood than fear; Loyalty, Fidelity, and Gallantry, are Vertues inseparable from the House of Ormond; we find e'm in every branch of it, and at all seasons. The Earl of Arran, Attacked in the late days of Confusion, a Bloody, Popular, and Formidable Error in its Camp, Fortified and Defended by all the strength of England; and for ever secur'd his own, and so much of the Publick reputation as was entrusted to him; managing that charge with the same Wisdom, Justice, and Fidelity he has done the Kingdom of Ireland, and many other great Commands, for the Honour and Service of the King. In the Young Earl of Ossery we have great assurances, the Grandfather and Father shall live in him, and receive the last rewards of Vertue Men are capable of in this World, to have their Honour and Happiness extend beyond their own beings. And herein the History of your Grace seems a Comment on the Fifth Commandment, you have always Honoured the Father of your Country, and your Days of Honour continue long in the Land, in your own Person, and your Illustrious Race. A useful President to England.

That I may approve my self an honest and grateful English-man, is one reason of my Address: I have also other obligations on me. Your Grace has been a Princely patron and encourager of Poetry; a Pleasant but Barren Country where my Genius and inclination has cast me. I am entangled among the inclinations of it, though it affords nothing but a good Ayre, a little vain reputation, and we must climb for it, and shall miss it too, if envy or ill nature can hinder us. There were no living, if some great Men elevated not only in Quality but Understanding above the rest of the World, did not Protect us from these Barbarians, because they know us. I beseech your Grace then give me leave to pay my Duty to you. Many and great are your Revenues in Honour, in the Camp, the Court, the Church, and the whole Common-wealth of Learning. The Poet may be employed as well as the Historian. I have made but a small Collection, but I have put it in hands that I hope will not soon embezle it. This Comedy has rais'd it self such a fortune in the World, I believe it will not soon run away. Give it leave to Honour it self with your great Name, and me with the Title of,

closer.signed: Your Graces most Humble and Obedient Servant. John Crown.

div.head: The Prologue.
div.l: WHat are the Charmes, by which these happy Isles
Hence gain'd Heaven's brightest and eternal smiles?
What Nation upon Earth besides our own,
But by a loss like ours had been undone?
Ten Ages scarce such Royal worths display
As England lost, and found in one strange Day.
One hour in sorrow and confusion hurld,
And yet the next the envy of the World.
Nay we are blest, in spite of us 'tis known,
Heavens choice for Us was better than our own.
To stop the blessings that oreflow this day,
What heaps o' Rogues we pild up in the way?
We chose fit tooles against all good to strive,
The sawciest, lewdest, Protestants alive.
They wou'd have form'd a blessed Church indeed,
Upon a Turn-coate Doctor's lying Creed.
To know if e're he took Degree is hard,
'Tis thought he'l have one in the Palace Yard,
Plot swallowers sure will Drink no more stuff down,
From that foul Pitcher when his Ears are gone.
Let us rely on Conscience, not on Cheats,
On Heavens wisdom, not on Juglers feats.
How greatly Heaven has our great loss supplyed?
'Tis no small Vertue heales a Wound so wide.
Nay in so little time to reer our Head,
To our own wonder, and our Neighbours dread.
They see that Valour Crown'd with regal Power,
They oft have seen what Lawrels Crown'd before.
Verse is too narrow for so Great a Name,
Far sounding Seas hourly repeat His Fame.
Our Neighbours vanquish'd Fleets oft wafted o're,
His Name to theirs and many a trembling Shore;
And we may go by His great Conduct led
As far in Fame as our Forefathers did.
At home he milder ways to Glory chose,
God like, by Patience he subdued his Foes;
Now they and their designs are Ruin'd all,
Beneath their fallen, accurst, Excluding Wall.
These are not all the blessings of this Isle,
Heaven on our Nation in a Queen does smile.
Whose Vertue's Grace by Beauty shine so bright,
All the Fair Sex to Vertue She'l invite;
And all the Clouds turn to a glorious Day,
By that Illustrious paire's united ray,
Who both Reform and Grace Us by their sway.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: 'TIs a hard Case, an Audience now to please,
For every Pallat's spoyl'd with some Disease.
Poor Plays as fast as Women now decay,
They'r seldom car'd for after the first day;
How often have I heard true wit call'd stuff,
By Men with nothing in their Brains but Snuff?
Each Shante Spark, that can the Fashion hit,
Place his Hat thus, role full Forsooths a Wit;
And thinks his Cloaths allows him judge of it.
The City Gallant, the Exchange being done,
Takes Sword at Temple-Bar which Nice stuck on.
Comes here and passes for a Beaugarzoon.
Audacious Vizards too, so fast do grow,
You hardly can the Virtuous from 'em know.
Nay Parents now not likely can endure,
Their Childrens faults, but what is worse procure.
Of Old the Mother full of Parent sway,
Kept Miss a Vassal to her work all day;
And to the Wooing Spark Miss was not brought,
But some fine Golden thing her wheedle wrought:
Now you shall meet young Lady and her Mother,
Rambling in Hackny-Coaches masqu't together;
Yes, and to say the truth, to work they go,
Fine work but— such as they will never shew.
Vnless some Nott to draw a Fool to Wed,
And then he finds Miss rare at work a Bed.
But the Grand Randevouz is kept of late,
Exact at Nine, hard by o're Chocholate,
Sad fate, that all the Christian Youth o'th' Nation,
Should be oblig'd to Jews for Procreation.
Nay, what is worse, that's, if reports be true,
Many a Christian Gallant there turns Jew;
That is, so oft some rotten Strumpet plyes him,
The Chirurgion's forc't at last to Circumcise him.
Our Bridges-street is grown a Strumpet Fair,
Where higling Bawds do Palmb their rotten Ware.
There Fowler like the watching Gallant Pores
Behind his Glove, to get a shot at Whores;
And from his tongue lets flye such charming Words,
That strait he carrys off the wounded Birds.
Another waits above in the great Room,
Till a new Cargozoon of Strumpets come.
There by three Glasses plac't the Affected Dunce,
Acts you Four Courtly-Nices all at once;
Our Gallerys too, were finely us'd of late,
Where roosting Masques sat cackling for a Mate:
They came not to see Plays but act their own,
And had throng'd Audiences when we had none.
Our Plays it was impossible to hear,
The honest Country Men were forc't to swear:
Confound you, give your bawdy prating o're,
Or Zounds, I'le fling you i' the Pitt, you bawling Whore—
This Comedy throws all that lewdness down,
For Virtuous Liberty is pleas'd alone:
Promotes the Stage to 'th' ends at first design'd,
As well to profit, as delight the Mind.

div.head: A COMEDY Call'd Sir Courtly Nice: OR, It Cannot Be.
ACT. I.
div.stage: Enter at several Doors Leonora and Violante. Scene, Lord Bellguard's House.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: MY Dear—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: My Dear, how is it with thee? What amendment in thy Brothers humour, and thy condition?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh! thou break'st my heart, for I love him extreamly, and am, I think, as well belov'd by him; but whil'st he has this Disease upon him so mortal to Liberty, dare venture on him no more, than if he had the Plague, or any other Distemper dangerous to Life. For what is life without Liberty? To be his Wife is worse than to be a Ghost, for that walks and enjoys a little chat sometimes, but I must be laid by a Conjurer call'd a Husband for my whole life, I would not be a Queen on the tearms; no nor on any tearms, because a Queen is confin'd to Forms, so fond am I of Liberty; but next to that I love your Brother; I wou'd give all the World to cure him, is there no way?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: None that I know off.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Must we then be for ever unhappy, I in the loss of him, and you in Eternal Slavery?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I might have Liberty, but on such tearms—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: What Tearms?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Marriage with such a Coxcomb, you know him— Sir Courtly Nice.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: A tempting Man, he has a vast estate.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: But incumber'd.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: With what?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: A Fop, 'tis morgag'd to a thousand expensive Follies, if it were not, I wou'd not drink water for the sake of a fine Bowl chain'd to the Well. The Youth I love has a fair and free Estate.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Mr. Farewel is it not?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ay, but he's forbidden Fruit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I know it to my sorrow.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: What's the reason?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: History must tell you. There has been a pique between our Families since the Conquest; none were thought truly of our Blood, that had not that Scurvy in it; because mine began to sweeten, my Father almost suspected my Legitimacy; and left me no Fortune but on condition I retain'd the Ancient mark of our House.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: There arises then your Brothers great Authority. He has the disposal of your Fortune, by consequence of your Person; Fortune is all Men seek now. They are so cow'd from Marriage, they will go Voluntiers into a Battle but must be prest to marriage; and 'tis the Shilling does it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Too true, But I believe Mr. Farewel of a more generous temper, he addresses still.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: It may be he does not know how it is with you, you have the Fame of Ten thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And the Money too, if I marry with my Brothers consent, not else.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: That's hard, but Mr. Farewel has enough for you both.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ay, if he will venture on me; yet if he will I know not how to come at him, I am so watch'd, not only at home but abroad. I never stir out but as they say the Devil does, with Chains and Torments. She that is my Hell at home, is so abroad.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: A new Woman.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No, an old Woman, or rather an old Devil; nay worse than an old Devil, an old Maid.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh! there's no Fiend so envious.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Right, she will no more let young People sin, that the Devil will let 'em be sav'd, out of envy to their happiness.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Who is she?

sp.speaker: Leo
sp.p: One of my own Blood, an Aunt.

sp.speaker: Vio
sp.p: I know her, she of thy bloud? she has not had a drop of it, these Twenty Years; the Devil of envy suck'd it all out, and left verjuice in the roome.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: True, this Aunt hangs on me like a daily Ague; but I had rather endure her, then be cur'd by such a nonsensical Charm as Sr. Courtly is. And nothing else can be applyed to me; for to assist my governing Aunt, there is a whole Army of Spies in the House; and over them two Spies General: And there my Brother thinks he shews a Master-piece of Policy.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Why? what are they?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Two, that will agree in nothing but one anothers confusion. The one is a poor Kinsman of ours, so fierce an Enemy to Fanaticks, that he cou'd eat no other meat; and he need no other Fire than himself to roast 'em, for he's always in a flame when he comes near 'em, his Name is Hot-head.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And I warrant thee the other is a Fanatick.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! a most Zealous Scrupulous one; with a conscience swadled so hard in its Infancy by strict Education, and now Thump'd and Cudgel'd so sore with daily Sermons and Lectures, that the weak ricketty thing can endure nothing.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Certainly these two, must make you sport.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! their faces, Dresses, Names are jests. The Fanatick's Name's Testimony.
Where is my Lord? Where's my Lord?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! I hear my Cholerick Cousin Hot-head.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Where's my Lord? Where's my Lord, I say?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What wou'd you do with my Lord?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Call him to an account if he were not my Cousin, cut his pate, it may be Cudgel him. Heaven be thank'd to Cudgel a Lord is no Scandalum Magnatum.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What's the reason of all this anger?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: He affront's me, he invites me to live in his house, and then keeps a Fanatick to make a jest o' me. He knows I sweat when I see one.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: May be he has occasion for one.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: What occasion? He is not in a Plot, is he? Fanaticks are good for nothing else that I know of.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Why not? Toads are good for something.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Ay, when they are hang'd and dryed, so is no Fanatick. He is such a canker'd Rogue, he does mischief when he's hang'd; let him spread Ink upon Paper and it raises blisters.— But here the Rogue is.
[Sirrah! Sirrah, What's your business in this House, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: What Authority have you to examine me, Friend?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Friend, you Dog! call me. Friend, I'le knock you down Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Poor Soul— poor Soul—

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p:
You are an Impudent Rascal to call me poor Soul— Sirrah, I have a Loyalty and a good Conscience, and that's a better Estate, than any
of your Party have; and if you live in the House with me, I'le settle it on you with a Pox to you.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Hot-head I know you well enough, I know you would hang us all if you could.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: I need not Sirrah, for Heaven be prais'd now you begin to hang your selves; I knew when Tyburn was bestow'd upon the Priests and Jesuits, the Fanaticks and Re-publicans wou'd not long be without it, for they are very fond of all Church Lands, come, Sirrah, if you live here, I'le make you turn over a new leaf, I'le make you go to Church, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: That's more than you do your self Mr. Hot-head, you go not often to Church.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: What then? I'm for the Church, Sirrah. But you are against the Church, and against the Ministers, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: I cannot be Edifyed by 'em, they are formal, weak, ignorant, poor Souls— Lord help 'em— poor Souls.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Ignorant? you're an impudent Rascal to call Men o' their Learning Ignorant; there's not one in a hundred of 'em, but has taken all his Degrees at Oxford, and is a Doctor, you Sot you.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: What signifies Oxford? can't we be sav'd unless we go to Oxford?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Oxford don't lye out o' the road to Heaven; you Ass.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Pray what do they learn at Oxford? only to study Heathens; they'l talk of Aristotle in the publick, they may be asham'd to name Aristotle among civil People.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Oh! you Sot.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Our Ministers are powerful Men. Oh! Forsooth I wish to Leo. you were under one of our Ministers; you wou'd find they wou'd pierce you forsooth; they wou'd go to your inward parts.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: This Rogue is talking Bawdy.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: They would shew you the great— great sinfulness of sin, that sin is one of the sinfullest things in the whole World.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: You senceless Rascal, what should be sinful but sin? what should be foolish but a Fool?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Are not these a ridiculous Couple?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Come this is very provoking, and very Prophane; I shall have a sad time on't in this wicked Family.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Wicked! Sirrah: What wickedness do you see in this Family?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ay, Mr. Testimony, now we are all concern'd, what Vices do you find among us?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Suppose I see not many Vices, morality is not the thing; the Heathens had morality, and forsooth would you have your Coachman or your Footman to be no better Men than Seneca?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: A Coachman a better Man then Seneca?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I wou'd have him be a better Coachman than I believe Seneca was.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Ay, and a better Christian too, or woe be to him. But truly I see great wantonness even in your self forsooth,— the very Cook debauches you.—

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: How? call the Cook!— Cook!— Cook!—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: The Cook debauch me, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: I mean by pampring you, Morning, Noon, and Night with one wanton kickshaw or another.—
You Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Sot.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Rascal, I thought the Cook had layn with my Cousin— Sirrah, you deserve to have your bones broke. Well Sirrah, since you find my Lords. Table is too Iusty, I'le have it guelded; I'le make you keep Lens, and fast Wednesdays and Fridays.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: I will not, I abhor it, 'tis Popery.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Then you shall fast Tuesdays and Thursdays.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: And then the Family will slander me, and say I do it out o' contradiction,— I will not do it, I do not love to grieve the weak.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: To grieve the strong thou mean'st, thy own strong stomack.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: You are offensive.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: I will be more. I will watch you Sirrah, and know why my Lord feeds such Rascals.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: I tarry not for his feeding, the Family is a sad Family, and I tarry out of pure Bowels.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Out of empty Bowels, which you have a mind to fill, and it may be you may fill other empty bellys, I mean among the Wenches, some of you Godly Rogues play such tricks some times. I'le watch you Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: And I'le watch you, my Spirit rises at this Man exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: These are a pleasant Couple.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Is not my Brother politick? These are to see no Provisions for wantonness be conveigh'd to me from abroad, and be sure they will not agree to deceive him. And that I may have none at home, My Brother will not venture a handsome Servant in the house; he swears he will not be Brother in Law to er'e a Butler or Footman in England; and he has cull'd for his Family, the most choice peices of deformity he cou'd find in the Nation. I believe they are now altogether in the Pantry, and my Aunt among 'em distributing their Breakfasts— the Monsters will be worth seeing— open the Door.—
sp.stage: The Scene is drawn, and a Company of Crooked, Wither'd, ill-look'd Fellows are at breakfast, and Aunt with them.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: How now? Who open'd the Door without my leave? Neice, this is one o' your Girlish tricks, will you always be a Child? Will you never learn staidness and gravity, notwithstanding the perpetual Counsel you have from me, the perpetual displeasure I shew at all sort of youthful Follies; do not you know how I hate impertinent Youth?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Or any sort o' youth to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p:
Do not I always tell you how sine a thing it is to be Grave; that Youth with Gravity is very passable, and almost esteem'd equal with years? Very wise Persons will not be asham'd to match with Grave Youth; daily experience shews it, and will you never leave? Fye— fye— fye— I
wou'd not for the World any Wise Sober Person o' Quality that has an Inclination for you, shou'd ha' seen this rudeness in you, to Expose your Aunt in this manner, in her undress; it might ha' created in him an aversion for you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: An aversion to me, to see your ill dress?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Madam, I hope you'l pardon the liberty I take in your presence.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh! good Madam.—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! Madam— pardon me— I know I commit a Solecism in good Manners,— but you are a Lady that has a great deal o' goodness, and a great deal o' worth.—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh! sweet Madam!—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! Madam! our Family has found it— you are pleas'd to Honour us with your Friendship. We may venture to expose our Frailties before you, Madam, you'l be so good to pardon— Madam—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh! Madam!—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Well really Madam— I wonder where my Neice learns her wantonness, we are the most reserv'd Family in the World. There were Fourteen Sisters of us, and not one of us married.—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I'st possible?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: To your great grief—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: We were all so reserv'd. Oh! Madam! no Man durst presume to think of us;— I never had three love Letters sent to me in my whole life.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh! strange!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! we were very reserv'd. Well Madam I am very much out o' Countenance to appear thus before you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, every thing becomes you Madam.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! you are very obliging Madam.— Do you hear Neece— learn o' this Lady?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: To flatter you.—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Madam I am extream unfortunate, the affairs o' the Family call me away from your sweet Conversation.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: the misfortune is mine, Madam.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! sweet Madam your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Your humbler Servant dear Madam. Ha! ha! ha! what Exit Aunt. ridiculous peice of Antiquity is this? Thy Brother has a great Honour for his Family since he will keep such a relick of his Ancestors as this.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: All the house is of a piece.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Nay if thou learn'st lewdness at home, thou hast a great Genius to it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Well, what do you think of my condition?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I like it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Like it?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ay, for I perceive your Brother has put the whole force of his Wit into this Form of Government; now if we can baffle it, he will find it is a dream fit for nothing but Utopia; and never torment himself and his Friends with it any more, then he'l be a faultless Creature, and all of us happy in our Loves, Here he comes.
Your Servant good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your most humble Servant Madam.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My Lord, why do you call him Lord? he's a Doctor and curing me o' the Palpitation o' the heart, Falling-sickness, Convulsions in the Eyes, and other such Distempers.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: A Doctor? a Quack by his false Medecines; shortly we shall see him mount the Stage, or stand at the Old— Exchange and cry a Cure for your Horns, a Cure for your Horns.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'm glad to see you so pleasant Madam.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: How can I otherwise chuse my Lord, and see your Family and Government?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Faith, Madam he that will have a Garden must inclose it, and cover tender Plants: This is a very blasting age to Vertue, 'twill not thrive without a covering.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ay, but my Lord, you force your ground too much, what Horns wou'd not grow in your Soyle? When wou'd not your Forehead sprout? Were I your Wife and thus kept, I shou'd spread like a Vine, and all the Walls in England wou'd not hold me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'm not o' that opinion, Madam.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Why shou'd you think better o' me than your Sister?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I judge very well of her, but must speak freely I think few Women may be trusted in this life, this World is, and ever was a great brothel; where? or with whom may a Woman be trusted? with ancient Ladies; they are the chief Beauty Merchants, venders of fine Love.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ladies o' that Profession.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! the most excellent, and most in Employ. Pedling Women cry Scotch Cloath of a groat a yard, stuff only fit for Footmen. But wou'd you have fine Beauty, Choice of Beauty, and with ease Security and Decency, go to your Lady Merchants; in Common houses the work is manag'd as slovenly as Religion in Conventicles, enough to put one out of conceit with it; but in Brothels o' Quality, Iniquity is carried on with that venerable order wou'd intice any one to Devotion.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Fye! fye!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And with that security. A Man may there enjoy a Lady whilst her Husband holds her Cards.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And shall the Lady o' the house know o' these things?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And manage 'em too; break the Lady to the Lovers hands; that's the advantage o' Quality, if a young Lady has not a natural amble, a poor Bawd cannot have access to teach her.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: What can a Lady o' Quality propound by such doings?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! many things. As Presents; and Pleasures. She has her house full of good Company, her Ears full of wanton Stories; her Eye full of tempting Sights, and now and then her Lips get a close kiss. Oh! Madam! do you think it does not warm an Elderly Lady's blood, to have a brisk young Spark always by her side? he is her Liquour of life, and though she never gets a full draught, a tast chears her heart.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Who are these Ladies? where do they live?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! you'd feign be acquainted with 'em? no such matter; and yet I'le tell you where they live.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Almost every where; where there is an Amorous Aunt, or over-indulgent Mother.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Mothers? will Mothers corrupt their Daughters?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, or if they wont Daughters will corrupt their Mothers. Things are so inverted, that Ladies who were honest all their Youth to be like their Mothers, turn lew'd in their old Age to be like their Daughters. There never was such an open and general War made on Virtue; young ones of Thirteen will pickeere at it, and by that time they are twenty, they are risen to be Strumpets General, and march in publick with their Baggage, with Miss, and Mass, and Nurse and Maid, and a whole train of Reformade sinners, expecting the next Cully that falls.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You talk of paltry husses.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Very good Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Gentlewomen o' those employments.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, purchase 'em. I have known a fair young Lady give all her Fortune to attend a Man o' Quality in his Bed-Chamber; be his chief Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Suppose so, what's all this to me? If they be bad must I be so?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Truly Sister, a rambling Woman let her be never so good a manager, will be apt to bring her Vertue as a Traveller does his Money, from a Broad peice to a brass Farthing: But say she does not, is reputation nothing? and let me tell you, Reputation will hang loose upon a galloping Lady; you may as well go among high Winds and not be ruffled, as among Men and not have your good Name blown over your Ears.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Those Winds blow where they list. A Woman is not secue rat home from Censure.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But you must allow a Jewel is not so safe in a Crow'd as when lock'd up.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Lock'd up? do you think to lock me up?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I think to secure thee, my dear Sister.

l.hi: Women like Cheney shou'd be kept with care,
One flaw debase's her to common Ware.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: Scene Violante's house. Enter Violante ' and a Servant.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: IS Mr. Farewel coming?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes Madam, he's just at the Door.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: That's well, if this brisk young Fellow, has but Love enough to undertake this work, and Wit enough to go through with it, we shall all be happy.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Where's your Lady? Madam, your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Your Servant Mr. Farewel; you are a happy Man, young, rich, and in the Ladies Favours.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I'm glad to hear that, Madam; who are these Ladies Madam,? a day, and hour of Youth and good Fortune is precious; and Ladies like Birds must be aim'd at whilst they hop about us, miss that opportunity you may loose 'em for ever. Therefore the Ladies, good Madam, quick, quick, for if you defer but half an hour, they'l be in love with some body else.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: No Mr. Farewel, there is one Lady more Constant, you'l own it when I name her; my Lord Belguard's delicate young Sister. What say you to her?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I adore her.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And dare you attempt her?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Dare I?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ay, for do not you know you are the only Man forbidden her.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Do I know of what Race I am, Madam? Never was such a pack of Fops as my Lord Belguard's Ancestors and mine. They lov'd wrangling more than we do intriguing; kept Lawyers instead o' Wenches, and begot upon their bodies, a thousand illegitimate Law Suits, the Terms they observ'd as duly as the River does the Tydes, and Land was carried too and frow, as mud is in the Thames. Nor were their quarrels so bitter about Land, as place; so big were their great hearts, they cou'd not come into one Room together, for fear of loosing place. My Lord Belguard's Father to end the difference, most piously endeavours to be a better Man than any of his Ancestors. That is to say a Lord.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And then the strife ended?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
Was more enflam'd. For my Lord was more insolent, as having Authority under the Broad Seal to be proud, by Consequence my Father more enrag'd; and both the old Gentlemen contended who shou'd have the greatest Estate in malice, and attain'd to be very considerable, and when
they dyed, endeavourd to settle it all upon us. But truly the young Lady and I most prodigally consum'd all our Portions at one look, and agreed to cut of the wicked Entail.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You did well, but how will you accomplish your desires? her Brother has such guards upon her.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Oh! 'tis Decreed! nor shall thy Fate oh! Brother! resist my Vow, though Guards were set on Guards, till their confounded Coxcombs reach'd the Skies, I'd or'e 'em all—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You are in a Rapture.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Ten thousand when ever I think of her.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: But how will you do this?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I have leagu'd with a Witch; at least a young Fellow that has more tricks than a Witch; he was a poor Scholler at Oxford, but expell'd for studying the Black Arts.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: For Conjuring?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, not only any Mans Pigs or Poultry, but Wife or Daughter into his Chamber. Nothing cou'd scape him, and he scap'd every thing. The Proctors watch'd more diligently for him, then a Benefice, and cou'd never catch him. The Grave Doctors abhor'd him worse than a Haeresie, and studyed more to keep him out of their Families, but he confuted their Skill, and they cou'd no more light upon him than on a jest.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I long to see him.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I ordered him to come hither to me.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Here's one Mr. Crack enquires for you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: That's he— bring him in—

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.p: Crack your Servant.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir, your humble Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir, I am told you ha' been an Oxford Scholler.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: A Scholler Madam? a Schollers Egg— emptyed by old suck. Eggs, of all that Nature gave me, and crumbled full of Essences, Hypostases, and other stuff o' their baking.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Why did not you apply your self to Divinity?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Leave Wenches for Pigs, Madam; 'tis true I may Wench then too, but it must be with Fear and Reverence, I hate that.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Why wou'd not you be a Physician?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: A Gold-finder Madam? look into Jakes for bits o' money? I had a Spirit above it. I had an ambition to be of some honourable profession; such as People of Quality undertake. As for instance, Pimping. A Pimp is as much above a Doctor, as a Cook is above a Scullion; when a Pimp has foul'd a Dish, a Doctor scours it.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: This is an arch Blade.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Oh! you are pleas'd to say so, Madam; 'tis more your goodness than my desert.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Well Mr. Crack, you know what you have undertaken.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I'le do't— The Lady's yours.— Give me some Mony.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: There, there.—

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Gold! thou Son o' the Sun, and Brother o' the Stars, Nutmeg o' comfort, and Rose o' delight, as my Friend the King o' Persia call's himself,— what can'st thou not do great Prince, if I be thy chief Minister?—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: This is a notable Fellow,— our next Plot must be to secure your Rival Sr. Courtly Nice.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Hang him, he secure's himself by his Foppery's, she despises him.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Not many Lady's do so.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Oh! no, Madam, he's the General Guitarre o' the Town, inlay'd with every thing Women fancy; Gaytry, Gallantry, Delicacy, Nicety, Courtesy.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And pray, put in Gold too.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: True Madam, Oh! the Ladies love to have him in their Chambers. and play themselves a sleep with him.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Well, I have provided one shall thrumble on him.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Surley.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Oh! Fire and Water are not so contrary, Sr. Courtly is so civil a Creature, and so respectful to every thing belongs to a Gentleman, he stand's bare to his own Perewig. Surly uncovers to nothing but his own Night-cap, nor to that if he be drunk, for he sleeps in his Hat. Sr. Courtly is so gentle a Creature, he writes a challenge in the stile of a Billet-doux. Surley talks to his Mistress, as he wou'd to a Hector that wins his Mony. Sr. Courtly is so pleas'd with his own Person, his daily contemplation, nay his Salvation is a Lookinglass, for there he finds Eternal happyness. Surley's Heaven at least, his Priest is his Claret Glass; for to that he confesses all his Sins, and from it receives Absolution and Comfort. But his damnation is a Looking glass, for there he finds an Eternal fire in his Nose. In short if you wou'd make a Posset for the Devil, mingle these two, for there never was so sweet a thing as Sr. Courtley, so sower as Surley. But how will you get 'em together? for nothing has power over Surley, but Claret and the Devil.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Yes I have. Heaven is pleas'd to think the Devil himself has not mischief enough to plague that ill-natur'd Rogue, and joyns me in Commission with him to torment him with Love; he loves me.—

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Love? can he love?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: So much, he neglects his Claret for me; and comes hither hourly to perform his Devotions to me, but in such a slovenly manner; 'tis such a Non-Conformist to all decent Ceremonies.

sp.speaker: Surley within.
sp.p: Where's your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
I hear him, we'l ha' sport with him. He abhors his Love worse than
Murder or Treason, for those are mischiefs to others, but Love he accounts High-Treason against his own damnable Person; and he's more asham'd of it, than he wou'd be of a Beasts Taile if it grew out of him. Therefore I'le conceal, and do you charge him with it, you shall hear how he'l renounce it, then will I appear like Conscience to a sick debauch, and you shall see what an aukard Penitent I'le make him.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Honest Surly, how do'st do?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Prethee look in my Water.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: In thy Water?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Ay, for I don't love to answer impertinent questions,

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Is it impertinent to enquire after the health of a Friend?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: A Friend? thy talk is more boyish than thy Face. Do'st thou think there are such Friends? thou believ'st there are Mair-maids and Centaures I warrant; for such Friends. Monsters that grow to some other Beasts, and are the least part o' themselves?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Why? hast thou no concern for any Beasts but thy self?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Yes Bird, for many things for my own sake; for Witty Men whil'st they drink with me, handsome Whores whil'st they lye with me, Dogs, Horses or Cattle whil'st they belong to me; after that, I care not if the Wits behang'd, the Whores be pox'd, and all the Cattle bewitch'd.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: A very generous temper.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: 'Tis a wise and honest temper. The pretended good nature is ill nature; it makes a Man an Ass to others he bears their Burden, a Rogue to himself, he cheats himself of his quiet and Fortune. I am so very honest to my self, if the whole World were hang'd it shou'd not rob me of a Minutes ease, I thank Heaven for it.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Was ever such a Barbarian?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Thou 'rt an Ass; which is the Barbarian, he that eats Man, or the Man that's eaten? The Rogue that grieves away my Flesh eats me, and is a Barbarian; so is he that with vexation gnawes himself; I am no such Cannibal.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Hast thou no compassion?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I know not what it is.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Suppose you see a Man o' Quality in misery.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Let him be in misery and be damn'd.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Are you not concern'd for his Quality?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: The less for that, because if he fancies the whimsey he has it to please him.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: To trouble him.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Then to comfort him I'le tell him he's the Son of a Whore, and his Grandfather rose by Pimping.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Suppose you saw a Man o' parts unfortunate?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Let his parts look after him.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: They'l afflict him.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Then to quiet him I'le tell him he's an Ass.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Have you no charity? do you never give any thing to the Poor?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: As much as any Man.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Does no Man give any thing?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Not to the Poor; they give it to themselves; some Fools have Diseases in their Natures, they never see any one in pain, but they feel half on't, and so they give money to ease themselves.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Ha' you no love for any thing?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I have Appetite.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Have you no love for Women?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I ha' Lust.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: No Love?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: That's the same thing, the word Love is a Fig-Leaf to cover the naked sence, a fashion brought up by Eve, the Mother of Jilts, she Cuckolded her Husband with the Serpent then pretendedto modesty and fell a making Plackets presently. And her Daughters take up the Trade, you may import what Lewdness you will into their Common-wealth, if you will wash it over with some fine Nmae. You may proclaime at Mercat-cross, how great an Adorer you are of such a Womans Charms? how much you desire to be admitted into her Service; that is, how lusty a Centaur you are, that the Horse in you is much the major part, and she shall receive all this without a blush, whil'st the Beast trots to her under the Name of a Lover; when if she had any Wit she'd know, a Lover is a more impudent Name than Whoremaster; for a Whoremaster throws all his Bombes at a whole City, your Lover wasts all his upon a single House. That when a Woman desires a Lover, she desires to have the whole Brute to her self.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: What do you laugh at Sir?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Only that your Mistress has heard your learned Discourses Sir. Pray appear Madam, and own you have lost your Wager, is he a Lover or no?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Here's a young Treacherous Rogue.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Yes— a Brutal one— are these your Sentiments of Love Sir? was it this you meant when you talk'd of Love? when we grow Lovers do we degenerate into Brutes? I thought there was a generous Passion, of which a Beast cou'd have no more sence, than he has of Musick or Poetry. And to such Love you pretended Sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I'le whedle her, (asideto Fa.) So I do still Madam, but why must I let a Boy Catechise me? I have that Musical, Poetical, Fantastical love, you speak of, and a pox on me for it; you'l neither be my Slipper, nor my Shooe, my Wench to slip on and of at pleasure, nor my Wife, that is a Whore buckled on.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You are charming in your expressions.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Mr. Surly, Madam, is a mistical peice, to be understood like a Prophecy, where Rams and He-Goats stand for Kings and Princes. Mr. Surly's, rank expressions must signifie Virtue and Honour.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: No, no, they signifie his own filthy meaning; and the truth is, love has no other sence, in this corrupt Age. Now if a Woman by blushes or otherwise, confesses she thinks a Man, a fine Gentleman, he to requite her sends her presently a Libel call'd a Billet-doux, where he in fine words tells her to her Face, he thinks her a Wench, and invites her to lye with him. This ruins all Conversation, Men are always driving their brutal appetites to the Plays, the Court, to Church, like Drovers their Beasts to every Market; and there's no conversing with 'em, unless you'l take their Cattel of their hands.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Madam, I love your in your own fashion, admire you, adore you, and the Devil and all, what wou'd you have?— Now will this simple Jade believe me?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: He calls you simple Jade, Madam, and say's you'l believe him.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: You Malapert Boy, why do you meddle in my business?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: 'Tis my business, she's my Friend, and I wont see her abus'd.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: A Friend to the Woman loves your Enemy, Tom-Fool?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: No, she hates him, and has quarrel'd with him, and I wou'd ha' had you step into his room.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Oh! ho!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Now who's the Tom-Fool?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I am, look you Madam, that Rogue despayr made me talk like an Ass, and I am sorry for it.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I know you are Sir, I know your base desire is for your punishment; confin'd to my Eyes, and I'le use you as you deserve.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Come, Madam, let me interpose; though you will not receive Mr. Surly as a half Horse, you may as a whole Ass, a Drudge, you know you have business most agreeable to his ill Nature, pray employ him.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Well; I'le make tryal of him, you pretend you love me Generously.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Yes, and Damnably.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Know then my Lord Belguard, is (as I have of late perceiv'd) sunk with the rest of the Age, into base opinions of Love and Women, that I am angry I ever had a good thought of him.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Look upon his address to me, as an affront, and will revenge it.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Better and better.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And you shall do it.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Best of all.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Do not you know Sir Courtly Nice?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: That you shou'd joyn knowledge with such a Fop? 'tis a question to be put to a Boy? I may know Philosophy, but to ask a Man if he knows a Horn-Book? for such a thing is this Fop; guilded on the out side, on the inside, the Criss Cross row, and always hanging at the Girdle of a Girl.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: You have describ'd him right. This rop has my Lord Belguard entie'd to accept his Sister with no Fortune, but her Birth and Beauty. Now if you'l break the Match, you'l be to me the most annable Creature in the World.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Or the most damnable, if you Jilt me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: In earnest of a farther favour here's my hand.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: There's the Devil in it. Tis transforming my shape, I am growing a Womans Ass, I feel the Ears prick out o' my skin already; and I must hoof it away with her load of Folly upon my back. Well I am thy Ass at present, but if thou Jilts me, I will be thy Devil.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: 'Tis the fittest Office for thee; thou art so like one already, you may pass for Twins. Now Mr. Farewel let's go in and Laugh.
sp.stage: Scene Lord Belguards House. Enter Hot-head and Testimony.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: He shall not speak with her, I dont approve of it.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: You approve Sirrah? what ha' you to do?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: I have Authority.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: You Authority?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Yes, from my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: You had it then out of his Kitchin, Sirrah; the Beef o' the Nation breeds all the Maggots in the Peoples heads. I am sometimes tempted to throw down their Porridge-pots, and spill the Divine Right of Presbitery. In short my Lord is a man of honour, and you have belyed him, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: It is well known I make a Conscience.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Ay, you Rogues making o' Consciences is a great trade among your Party, and you deserve to loose your Ears for it.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: I mean I keep a Conscience.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Y'ave reason Sirrah, it keeps you; but that an honest Lord shou'd give money for a Rogues false Conscience.— Oones!—

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Well but dont swear.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Sirrah, who swears?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: dee hear?— don't swear I say.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Oones! Sirrah, don't preach to me.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Don't swear then.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Sirrah, if you preach to me, I'le cut your Pate.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Had I a Sword 'twere more than you cou'd do.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: How now Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Nay but don't throttle me, don't Godfrey me.

sp.speaker: Aunt.
sp.p: What's the noyse? what's the rudeness, Cousin Hot-head? you a Gentleman, and make a Bear-Garden of a Persons of Honours house?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Better make a Bear-garden of it than a Conventicle; here's a Fanatick Rogue ordain'd ruling elder o'th' Family by my Lord, as the Rogue says, so he undertakes to govern and Preach.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: And you undertake to Govern and correct? Cousin no body Governs here but I; if he had committed faults, you shou'd have brought him before me.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Oh! you'd have him enter'd in your Office?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p:
What do you mean? obscenely? you are confident You are the first
Gentleman that offer'd to say a wanton thing to me.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: To your great sorrow.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What's the quarrel here?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: There's a Taylor wou'd fain speak with you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: All this noyse to introduce a Taylor?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: He can't get through this Fellows narrow Conscience, yet there is room for a whole Common-wealth.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Call in the Taylor; there must no Cloaths be made without my orders, that I may see 'em modest.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: A Taylor? I order'd no Taylor.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: How now, Sir? what are you?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: A Taylor, Madam.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Who sent you? I know you not.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Your own Taylor, Mr. Stitch, Madam.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: How chance he came not himself?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: He's sick, Madam.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: And can you work well, for we are very hard to please? There's scarce a Taylor in Town can make me endure to see my self.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: The fault lyes in— Fifty— Fifty—.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Indeed Madam, I must needs say my Country men are not the best Taylors in the World. This is a fine Nation, and all spoyl'd by the Taylors. Heaven makes the Women Angels, and Taylors make 'em Hedg-hogs; 'tis a sad sight to see 'em, now I'le make an Angel of a crooked Pin.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Ay, where did you learn your Skill?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: In France, Madam.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: In France? then Friend I believe you are a Papist.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Sirrah, I believe you are a Presbyterian.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Friend, if you be a Papist I'le ha' you before a Justice.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Sirrah, if you be a Presbyterian, I'le kick you down Stairs.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: What are you Friend?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Ay, what are you Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What am I? why, I'm a Taylor, I think the Men are mad.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Intolerable; Mr. Testimony pray leave us, and Cousin Hot-head, I shall desire the same of you, unless you'l behave your self like a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: I will behave my self like a Gentleman, for I'le know of my Lord when he comes home, if he has given this Rogue Authority over me; if he has I'le demand Satisfaction of him; if he be innocent woe be to your prick-ears, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: I fear you not.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Mr. Testimony, I once more desire you'l give us liberty.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p:
Yes, Forsooth, I dare trust the young Gentlewoman with you, Forsooth
— you are a grave— Gentlewoman and in years— Forsooth.—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: In years, rude Clown.—

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: And truly she's a very pretty sweet Woman, and deserves to have great care taken of her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Well Sir, we'l excuse the care at this time.—

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Pretty Woman.—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Pray leave us—.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Sweet Woman— I profess she's strangely alluring, I had best retire least I fall into frailty, and be discovered.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Now, Madam, before I take measure of you, I'l shew you some Patterns— please you to look upon some Madam, you have judgment—.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Let me see.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: To you, Madam, I wou'd recommend this peice.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Mr. Farewel's Picture? oh! I Sirrah! now I guess thee— my Dear— Dear—

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Have a care o' your Aunt Madam.— I have a Letter too.—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Give it me— quick— quick—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: These are pretty Silks.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: The best in France, Mdaam.
Where's my Sister?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My Brother? I hope he does not know thee.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: No, if he does I'm a dead Man.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Hast thou no disguise for fear he shou'd?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Only this great pair of Spectacles.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What Fellow's this?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: A Taylor.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not your Taylor?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: No, he's sick and sent this Fellow in his Room.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How comes such a young Fellow to wear Spectacles?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Young my Lord? I'm above Five and Fifty.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thou bear'st thy age well.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Ay, every where but in my Eyes I thank Heaven.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This Fellow may be a Bawd for ought I know, I'le watch him.
sp.stage: Aunt views the Patterns, Bell. stands behind his Sister, and watches Cr. Cr. mean while puts his Measure before, and delivers her a Letter.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I perceive your Ladyship likes the Pattern I shew'd you first.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I have seen the whole piece.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: And your Ladyship likes it?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! very well.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I'le assure you, Madam, you'l like it mightily when 'tis upon you, and you have a sweet body to work for. I do not doubt, Madam, but to get a great deal o' credit and a great deal o' Custome by you, among the Ladies, as soon as ever they see my work.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Well let's see your work, and I'le say something.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: That you shall and speedily, Madam, I'le bring you home as sweet a peice o' Work, as ever you had in your Life. You'l look upon the Pattern I shew'd you last?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: That's for the inside; do you like much Bombast, Madam?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No—.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Well, Madam— I ha' taken a Surveigh o' your fine Body— now you shall be pleas'd according to your own hearts desire— your Servant Madam—.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well Sister— prepare to receive a Visit from Sr. Courtly Nice, this Afternoon.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! dear! then I must dress. He's a great Critick.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: She designs him for her self, wou'd she cou'd get him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sr. Courtly and I have agreed; pray give him your promise.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: So soon? 'twill be fulsome, he's abstemious.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Therefore take him whil'st he has an edge.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You use to despise Fools, how chance you marry amongst 'em?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Because none but Fools will marry. Wits are but few and commonly poor; Fools are numerous and rich. Fortune is as fond of those bits of Men, as Bigots are of Reliques; wraps 'em in Silver.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Better they were buryed. A Fool in a Coach is like a Knave in a Pillory, the Object of publick derision.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! there are few to deride 'em, many to admire 'em, so many, I have oft admired how one Apple,
sp.l: Shou'd such Diseases in old Adam breed.

l.hi: That from his Loyns not Men, but Wroms proceed.

div.head: ACT. III.
div.stage: Scene, Covent-Garden-Square. Enter Farewel and Crack meeting.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Oh! the News! the News! art thou an Angel or a Devil? bring'st thou Joys or Torments?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Joys! joys! joys!

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Angel! Angel! Angel!

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: In the first place I deliver'd your Picture.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Rare.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: And she kissed it.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: kissed it?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Sweetly, wantonly, lasciviously. She set me so on fire, I kiss'd all the Wenches as I came along, and made their moyst lips fiz again.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Oh! Rogue! Rogue! delicious Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Then I deliver'd the Letter, and before her Brothers face.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Before his face? ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Prepare this Night to be the happyest o' Mortals. Give me some more Mony.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Mony? I'le sell my Land rather than thou shalt want. That one Inheritance will purchase me two, one in Love, and another in laughing at this politick Brother.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: No, no, Inheritances as for laughing, I believe you will have an Anuity for life; but for Love you'l only have a lease for three or four Years.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Pleasant Rogue! here's Money.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: So, so, I wish you joy I wish you joy.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: See Surly going to my Rival; my affair thrives admirably.
sp.stage: Enter Surly. Knocks, enter a Servant.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Is Nice within?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Nice Sir?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Ay, Nice Sir; is not your Masters name Nice.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: 'Tis Sir Courtly Nice.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Well Sir, if I have a mind to clip half his Name, 'tis not Treason, is it Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I believe not Sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Then get you in, and tell your Master I'd speak with him

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: What sort o' domineering Man is this?
sp.stage: Scene, a Chamber— Sir Courly Nice dressing, Men and Women singing to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Very fine! extreamly fine. Gentlemen and Ladies, will you do me the favour to walk in, and accept of a small Collation? I am in some hast to dress upon an extraordinary occasion. You'l Pardon me?— your very humble Servant—.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Very fine.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: You Sot, 'twas very barbarous.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Your honour said 'twas very fine.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: You Clown, don't you know what belongs to a Gentleman? Complaisance is the very thing of a Gentleman, The thing that shew's a Gentleman. Wherever I go, all the World cryes that's a Gentleman, my life on't a Gentleman; and when y'ave said a Gentleman, you have said all.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Is there nothing else Sr. belongs to a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Yes, Bon mine, fine Hands, a Mouth well furnish'd—

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: With fine Language—.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Fine Teeth you sot; fine Language belongs to Pedants and poor Fellows that live by their Wits. Men of Quality are above Wit.. 'Tis true for our diversion sometimes we write, but we ne'r regard Wit. I write but I never writ any Wit..

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: How then Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I write like a Gentleman, soft and easie.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Does your Honour write any Plays?

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: No, that's Mechanick, I bestow some Garniture on Plays, as a Song or a Prologue.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Then your Honour is only a Haberdasher o' small Wares?

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: A Haberdasher, you sawcy Rascal?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: Here's one Mr. Surly to visit your Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Surly, what the Devil brings him hither?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: He has been walking about the Rooms this quarter of an hour, and wou'd not let me bring him in, till he had fould 'em all with his dirty Shoes.

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: A Nauseous, Beastly, Sloven, Clown, Fool, Sot.

sp.speaker: Dear Mr.
sp.p: Surly your most humble Servant. (Sir Co. Bows to receive him.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: What, are you unbu— buckling my Shooe?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Surly— he stinks horribly— aside.) How came I to enjoy— a very Polecat— aside.) This great happyness?— pox! foh! you and I have been aside.) long piquee, and I'm amaz'd to see you at my levee.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I begin to think, thou art a good honest Fellow, and have a mind we shou'd no longer be two lo— lo— Loggerheads, but one.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Dear Sir, you are always so divertising; Well Sir, shall I beg a favour of you?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Leave to dress before you, Sir. I am to meet some fine Women to day, one presently.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Prethee dress, and be damnd— shall we di— dine together?

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I suppose, and Sup too—.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: That's kind, well when?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: About Five o' clock Sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: In the Kings Box, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Must you and I, dine in the Kings Box?

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: Oh! dearest! I beg your Pardon Ten thousand times, I thought you ask'd me where I shou'd meet the Lady.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Pox o' the Lady; I ask where we shall Dine?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Really Sir I don't know, I can't put my head into one o' your beastly eating houses, nor swallow the filthy meat you eat there, if you'd give me One hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Filthy Meat? Sir I eat as good Meat as you do.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! dear Mr. Surly, no doubt the meat in its own nature may be very innocent; but when once it has committed familiarity with the beastly Fists of Cooks and Butchers, 'tis to me an unpardonable Sinner. My Butcher cuts up all his Meat with a Fork.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Does he cut up an Ox with a Fork?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Ay, and he cuts up an Ox as neatly as a Lady does a Partridge.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Well, then I'le accept o' thy Dinner.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Dear Sir, your most humble Servant; pox on him (aside) I wish I be capable o' the great happyness. For I came but last Night from my Country house, and I question whether I have all things in order or no, Whos's there? are all things brought from my Country house?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: No Sir, your Butler has forgot your Salt.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Left my Salt? careless Rascal. Let him take Horse immediately.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir he's rid post for it.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Rid post for Salt? whether?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: To my Country house.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: How far's that off?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: But a little way, not above Forty miles.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Send Forty miles out o' London for Salt? Is there not Salt enough in London for you?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Ay, stuff pawm'd by Butlers and Waiters, they take up the Wenches coats, then handle the Salt.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Here's a Rogue— (aside) well come let's drink a Glass o' Wine then.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p:
Oh! dear Mr. Surly, if you name Wine, you make me throw up my Soul. I have abhor'd Wine ever since I was in France, and saw what
barbarous Education they give that generous Creature. Duce take me, Sir, if the Clowns don't press all the Grapes with their filthy naked Feet. Oh! beastly nasty Dogs! no wonder we are poyson'd with their Wine.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Prethee what o' that? the Wine purges before it comes over.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Lord Mr. Surly what a Phrase is there? you'l Pardon my Freedom, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Most civil Coxcomb (aside) well what must we drink for drink I must?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I have several drinks of my own composing at your Service, as Mead, Syder, Ale.—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Ale? there's Sauce for a Woodcock. Come let's tast a Bottle.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Fetch a Bottle; This Fellow will Poyson me—.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Well I come to request a favour o' thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your most humble Servant Sir, how de'e ' like this Cravat?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: What's that to my business? I come to make a request to thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: 'Tis well tyed too, with a great deal o'humour.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: A Pox on thee, mind me.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your most humble Servant Sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I am going to make Love.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Before you drink Sir?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Before I drink Sir—.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Well Sir, since you'l have it so, I'le wait on you down stairs.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Is the Devil in the Fellow? I tell thee I'm going to make love.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Lord Sir, I beg your pardon a thousand times.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: And I come to beg thy assistance.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! dear Sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: For thou hast a knack on't. Thou art the only Court Card Women love to play with; the very Pam at Lantereloo, the Knave that picks up all.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, you are so obliging;— and stinking— Pox take him.—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: And 'tis a very pretty Woman I'm in love with; my Lord Belguard's Sister Leonora; thou know'st her.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: The Rogue's my Rival, he was born for my confusion (aside.) Ay, Sir, I have the honour of some small acquaintance there.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Prethee speak for me.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! dear Sir, you have a great Talent of your own:

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: But thine's a better. One thing I am sure thou may'st do, there's an abominable Fop makes Love to her, and I am told is to marry her; prethee tell him he's a Son of a Whore.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Really Sir I'm unfortunate; I ha' no manner o' Genius to that sort o' Conversation.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Say my words. Tell him if he proceeds, I'le not only Libel him, but tweag him by the Nose, Kick him, Cudgel him, and run him through the Guts. Prethee tell him this.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! pray Sir give me Ayr.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Prethee do.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Sir I am ready to—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: And thou wilt tell the Puppy this?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I will upon my Soul.
sp.stage: Enter a Servant with Wine and Glasses.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Then thou art an honest Fellow— so, is the drink come? fill a Glass, why two Glasses? do you think I cannot drink after your Master?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Pox o' your Complyment—.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Here Nice, my Mistresses health.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: What misery is this Beast imposing on me? he coughs in the Glass too—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Pox on't, a whole gulp went the wrong way, come off with it 'Tis my Mistresses health.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: This Fellows the Devil—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Off with it, Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I never was so embarass'd since I was born.—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Oones! off with it.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I must take the beastly portion down, but I shall be most horrible sick after it.—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: So, now thou art an honest Fellow, now I'le kiss thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: The Devil thou wilt? more miseries? (aside.) nay but Mr. Surly.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I swear I will.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Nay but you'l disorder me.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I swear I will.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: But Sir I'm going upon your occasions to your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Nay then I'le give thee two kisses, one for thy self and another for her.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Hell. (aside) nay but Mr. Surly.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I swear I will.
This Bottle Beer is damn'd windy— well honest Nice farewell to thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Who's there? I'm sick to death,— to death!— lead me in— get my bed ready— and a Bath— and some Perfumes— I'm sick to death,— I'm dead.
sp.stage: Scene Lord Belguard's House. Enter Bell. with Farewel's Picture in his hand.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thou horrid Vision! wou'd I had met with the worst Fiend in Hell, rather than thee; in thee there is a Legion exciting me to Blood— blood— Who's there?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: My Lord—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Coach— to blood— blood—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: To Blood? what means my Brother?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Be gone:

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: To whom do you speak?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Bless us; Nephew what ailes you?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Alas my Lord, I fear you are a going to quarrel.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, I'm going to punish one who Violates my Fathers, my Will and calls my Mother Whore.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What execrable Wretch is that?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thy self.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, what dost thou else but proclaim our Mother false, when she conceiv'd a thing so opposite to all our Fathers race as thou art?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: In what?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: In Infamy; when was there a spot in our name, till Heaven for our sins sent thee among us? and I am going to destroy thee in thy lewd undoer

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I know of no reproach in our Family but your madness, destroy that. What are your Spyes and Coxcombs, but so many Capital Letters, wherein you write over your Door, My Sister is a wanton Woman.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis truth, you are not only a wanton, but a wicked Woman; not only Intrigue, but with the Enemy of our Family, Farewel.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I am betray'd—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Do you blush?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: At your Folly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Dare you deny it?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Who dare accuse me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This Picture, which I found in your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Horrid Creature!— I shall swoon away.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: How shall I bring off this (aside) All this noise for a Picture? if you had found a little humane Effigies in swadling Clouts, there might ha' been some squawling.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Do you laugh at your shame?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She shall ha' no cause.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Do, kill me, before you know whether he's guilty or no.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'le know it from himself. If he denys it, it will be some revenge to make him stab his Soul with Lyes. He shall swear not only that he never did, but never will send so much as an Imagination to you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Do, if you wou'd force him hither, what charm to a Man of spirit, like daring?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She speaks sence in that.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: If you wou'd be fighting, fight your own jealousie, which abuses you worse than Mr. Farewel can do, my Honour protects you from him; but neither Wit or Honour, can guard you from the rude insolence of your jealousie, which is now sending you of an Errant, a Footman o' Spirit wou'd scorn, to proclaim the dishonour of your own Sister. Fye! Fye!

sp.speaker: Bell,
sp.p: And so I must sit down tamely with this abuse?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You are not abus'd, the Picture was found at Church.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: At Church? do you intrigue at Church?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: They do nothing else, the Church is almost as bad as the Porch.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Nay there's shameful doings, that's the truth on't, it provokes my Flesh to see how the young Men fling their Eyes about.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And not upon her.—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: But 'tis no marvail; when Women will encourage 'em. No Fellows dare gape upon me, because I never encourage Fellows.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: A Face of Fifty is small encouragement.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay no wonder the Devils cause thrives, he has a numerous Clergy, Heaven has but one Minister in the Church, and whil'st he is Preaching Divinity, the Devil has a thousand of both Sexes, by all the Oratory of looks and dresses, preaching Fornication and Adultery.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Too true, well she's certainly undone. I dare not examine her Breasts, if there shou'd be any thing in 'em, I shou'd dye.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: In my breasts?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Ay, Gentlewoman, do you think I regard your Flim flam story o'the Church?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Tis not my story, my Woman found it in Westminster Abby, at Prayers, and I knowing what work wou'd be made with it, commanded her to burn it, and she has dar'd to dissobey me.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam, I thought to have presented it to a Friend o' mine; and laying it out o' my hand unfortunately in your Honours Chamber, my Lord found it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! how nimbly she takes the lye at the first rebound?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Out upon you; I'm extream sick— lead me in— not you— you are not fit to touch a Woman o' my Virtue. These things have strange impression upon me.—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That you don't share in 'em—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pray, Sister, go out o' my sight, you are an horrour to me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Your own Dreams are. Y'are as mad as a Prophet, you have always before your Eyes a Vision of Horns and Whores.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: All this goes upon the score of Farewel's heart blood if he be guilty, I'le make enquiry presently, and search at what gap this Treachery entred.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! unfortunate negligence!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Who's there, Cousin Hot head, Testimony?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Oh! are you here?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, to your sorrow, if you have play'd me false.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: You ha' serv'd me finely.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Do you first complain?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Coupled me with a Dog?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But you ha' Coupled my Sister Sir.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: With a Fanatick Rogue.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No— with a finer Gentleman. Who brought this Picture?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: The common Fire-fork of Rebellion.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Fire-fork.— Fork me no Forks— Who brought this Picture?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: The rotten rump shou'd ha' been burnt— when 'twas only Roasted.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The rotten Rump— Answer me, or i'le fight thee.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Answer you what?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Who brought this Picture? I found it in my Sister's Chamber.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Then your Fanatick Rogue conveigh'd it thither to make me suspected, out of his malice to the Common-Prayer. I'le cut the Rogue to peices.
sp.stage: Enter Testimony with a great Sword by his side.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Testimony.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: I am here.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How now, Sworded?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: To preserve my Life. My life is threatned by that bloody Papist.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: How, Sirrah? dare you think of fighting me?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Yes, and hope to do it, through Providence.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Drawing before me?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Will you protect a Fanatick? I see what you are.
Well Sirrah, though I may not cut your Throat, i'le choak you Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: De'e, hear the bloody Papist? He'l throttle me.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Sirrah, i'le cram the Oaths of Allegiance, and Supremacy into you, and they'l stick in your Throat, though Treason wont, and so i'le to a Justice presently.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And stay with him, and never plague me more. Now Sir do you resolve my question.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: I do resolve I will not take the Oaths.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I do not ask you about the Oaths.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Why, if you ask me Ten thousand times, I will not take the Oaths.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Did one ever see such a Coxcomb?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Call me what you please, I will not take the Oaths— So do your worst.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A very fine account of my business.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: My Lord a Gentleman desires to speak with your Honour.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'm not to be spoke with, i'm a broad— my Soul is— in the heart of Farewel, ripping it up for this Secret. What Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: One from th' East-Indies, My Lord, he brings a Letter from your Uncle Rich.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He comes in a Storm; he will find worse Weather here, than any he met at Sea. But i'le endeavour to compose my self— admit him—
sp.stage: Enter a Man drest like a Merchant.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: My Lord, your Lordships most humble Servant. I perceive your Lordship has forgot me; you will know me better, when I acquaint you, who I am. My Father had the honour of being a Retainer to your Lordships Father, of Honourable memory; and sent me some Years since to the East Indies, in the Service of your Noble Uncle, Mr. Rich. My name is Waytewel.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Waytewel, I am glad to see you, truly you are so chang'd, if you had not told me who you was, I shou'd never ha' known you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I believe so my Lord— for I'm sure you never saw my Face before, but the Picture of it you have— for Waytewel was my Picture. (aside) Time and Travels will alter a Man, but truly I have lost nothing by my Travels but my Countenance; and in the room have gotten what's better, a convenient small competency of some Seven or Eight thousand pound; Heaven and your Uncles love be prais'd. I have brought Your Lordship some Letters from your Noble Uncle, and a small Present of some Threescore thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Only the trouble of it, my Lord. Your Uncle contracted in th' Indies an intimate Friendship with Sir Nicholas Calico, President for the East India Company. Sir Nicholas dyed, and left most part of his Estate (which was near a Hundred thousand pound,) to his only Son, Sir Thomas. But poor Sir Thomas happen'd in his Fathers Life time to fall into a Distemper, which gave him a scurvy flaw in his Brain, that Sir Nicholas left him and all his Estate to your Uncles Guardianship. Now your Noble Uncle perceiving his affairs are like to detain him many Years in th' Indies, and fearing if he shou'd dye, poor Sir Thomas might be cheated of all; he has like a Worthy and honest Gentleman, sent Sir Thomas and all his Estate to your Lordships care, as these Letters will testifie. I suppose your Lordship is well acquainted with your Uncles Hand and Seal.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I am, and this is his Hand and Seal reads— um— um— um— to preserve him from being cheated here, or beg'd in England, I take the boldness to recommend him, to the care of so Noble a Person as your Lordship— um— um— um—. Well Sir the Letter expresses what you told me.— Where is the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I brought him along with me; he's in the next room, my Lord. Poor Gentleman, he has the oddest Phrases and ways with him. He will needs be attended like a great Indian Mandarine, or Lord.
