And has brought with him several Siamites and Bantammers, that serve him as his Slaves, in the ridiculous Dresses and Modes of their own Countries. we had such a gaping Rabble after us, as we came along.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pray call him in, I long to see him—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: — Sir Thomas— pray come to my Lord.
sp.stage: Enter Crack ridiculously drest, attended by Men, in the Habits of Siamites, and Bantammers.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Which is the Peer?

sp.speaker: Man,
sp.p: This is my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Great Peer, your extream humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir, you are recommended to me, by my Uncle.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I know it my Lord, and am most incomparably oblig'd to him—. He is a Person, my Lord, that as to the altitudes of Friendship, and the most glorious Circumstances of a Singular Person, is not to be cast up by the Logarithmes of Oratory, nor his Latitude to be taken by the quadrangle of Circumlocution.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So— I find I shall ha' store o' Non-sence.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: My Lord, I'm a Person that as to the Circumstances of Mony, am not indifferently contemptible; and as to the circumstances of Honour, I am by profession a Merchant, by Generation a Knight. Sir Nicholas Calico applying his Person to my Mother, was the Author of, Sir, Your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So the Letter says.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: The Letter contains Verity.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pox I shall be teaz'd.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: One thing more Sir, I am a Person that as to understadning, am under the circumstances of Witchcraft. I lov'd in th' Indies, a fair Christian Curiosity, and a nauseous Indian Baggage, had a mind to apply to my Person her Tawny Circumstances; and finding she cou'd not obtain her Ambition, applys her self to an Indian Bawd, and Bewitches me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pshaw! Bewitch! what stuffs here?—

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Bewitches me Sir, what follow's thereupon? a loathing in me of Females? I abhor Women; fall into Agonys when I see Women. Pray let me see no Women.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You shall not Sir.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Pray My Lord, no Women.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'le warrant you Sir.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: But as much Supper as you please, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You shall Sir.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: You are highly civiliz'd.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I told Your Honour he had such odd ways; well My Lord, as soon as the Ship is come up the River, which will be in few days, I'le bring the Captain to wait upon Your Lordship, with the account of Sir Thomas his Estate, Aboard; which will amount to Forty thousand pound, besides Ten thousand pound he has brought a shore in rough Diamonds. So, My Lord, your very humble Servant. Sir Thomas your Servant I leave you in good hands.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'le order things for you. I must dispose this Man quickly, for i'm horribly weary of him, and also impatient to go about my Affairs.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Tis he— I'm sure 'tis he—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How now Sister? what's your business here?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Staring at this strange sort o' Man.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You were no Woman else— pray get from him speedily.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You are not jealous of a Mad-man sure? he's mad is he not?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, and impertinently brings me vexation too from the Indies, at a time when I've enough at home, as every Man has, that keeps a Woman. Pray get from him, he hates to see Women.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Hates to see Women? ha! ha! Sir Thomas Calico your humble Servant, you are welcome from the Indies; but have a care of being discover'd, least you be under the circumstances of a Cudgel.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Truly Madam, I expect to have something stick by my ribs presently, that is to say a good Supper; which I have order'd. My Lord and I will sup together, and you and Mr. Farewel.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: We sup together? where? in the Grave? a fatall accident has ' hapned, will bring us both thither. My Brother has found Mr. Farewel's Picture in my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: He shall not keep it, he shall deliver both Picture and jealousie.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Then thou art a Master. I told him my Woman found it in Westminster-Abby; may be thou may'st make something out o' that?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Stay let me consider Westminster-Abby, or the Abby of Westminster— um— um— Let me alone— begone— he comes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come Sir, let me wait on you to your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Hold, my Lord, a word, I have business of great consequence, I must humbly apply to your understanding.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So, I must be hindred with more Non-sence.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I've in the Indies, a delicate peice of my Fathers Rib, I beg your Lordship to advise me in the disposal.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! dispose it how you please, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: 'Tis a Sister I mean, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! that's something.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: She's sweet and slender as a Clove, and is worth two Millions o' Coxcombs— Three hundred of 'em comes to Three Farthings; 'tis a Chinese Mony. This Mony makes her much sought in Marriage: The great Hobbommoccoes o' the Indies come gallopping upon Elephants, Camels, Rhinoceroses, and Oxen to see her. Now my Father was under the circumstances of great obligation, to a Gentleman in England; and out o' gratitude to him, ordered me on his Death bed, to bestow my Sister on his Son, and Heir, if his actions have any sort o' smile in 'em to his incompatible Father, which is the query. Pray resolve it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: First let me know the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: You shall, I'le give you a Map of his Face, a Picture contain'd in my pocket.— ha!— I ha' lost it,— I ha' lost it—.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Tell me his Name, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I ha' dropt it out o' my pocket.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I, but his name.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I ha' dropt it out o' my pocket.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha' you dropt his Name out o' your pocket? his Name Sir?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Oh! his Name, I'le tell you both his Name, and Cogname. His Name is Andrew, his Cogname Farewel.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Farewel? what comes into my head? Sir can you guess where you might loose this Picture?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: A guess may be obtain'd— by the Prayers of Marriners—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No other way? those I seldome hear of—

sp.speaker: Cr
sp.p: — I was drawn down— stay let me see— remembrance begins to be idle— has London no place in the West?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Ay, but something very West? something call'd West?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes— there's West-Smithfield.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: That's not th' appellative. Is there no Monster in the West, call'd Westmonster?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Westminster I believe you mean.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Y'ave nick'd it it. To Westminster I rode, to behold the Glorious circumstances o' the Dead; and diving into my pocket, to present the representer with a Gratification, I am fully confirm'd, I then lost it; for my Eyes and the Picture had never any rencounter since.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This exactly agrees with my Sisters story, what a Prodigious thing is this? a discovery o' my Sisters innocence, sent to me from th' Indies, in a heap o' Non-sence? and in so Critical a minute; excellent Providence?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What's an excellent Providence, Sir, that I ha' lost my Picture?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No Sir, that I ha' found your Picture.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Found my Picture?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, 'twas found by a Friend o' mine, in Westminster-Abby— there it is—

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Oh! my Picture!— my Picture!— my Picture!—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! my eas'd heart!

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Oh! my Picture! my Picture! my pretty Picture!
My Lord I must requite this favour, open that Casket, and give my Lord a handful of Diamonds.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A handful o' Diamonds.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Ay, my Lord, I beg your Pardon for the inconsiderableness o' the Present.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Inconsiderableness? what a Market wou'd some make o' this Man?— put up your Diamonds.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: By no means, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Put 'em up Sir, or you'l dissoblige me.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: You overwhelm me with Favours, I wish I had you at my house in Bantam.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir; we are better where we are.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: My Lord, you put me under the circumstance o' blushing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pray let me put you into a Chamber, to rest your self.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Rest is good— yours humbly—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yours as humbly— What a Fire did I kindle in my house, to clear the Air of a Pestilence, was not in it? my Sister and all my Family are innocent. But what a fantastick thing is Womens Honour?

l.hi: Whil'st She enjoy it, 'tis not seen or known,
And yet when lost She's utterly undone.

div.head: ACT. IV.
div.stage: The Scene continues. Enter Violante and Leonora laughing.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: HA! ha! ha! what an excellent Fellow is this? what Engines he has in his head? not only to wind himself into my Lords house, but the Picture out of his hands?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: He undertakes to bring Mr. Farewel hither to Night. If he engag'd to bring him in a Church with a Parson to marry us, I wou'd not doubt it.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Certainly my Lord must be in a most mortified humour; now is the time to scarify him, and take out his Worm.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Here he comes, now will I carry my self with all the insolence of a Vertuous Woman.
So my Lord have your Slaves been gathering any more scatter'd smiles o' mine? what loads o' that Gold Sand have your Asses brought home?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: They have heard all, now I am asham'd to shew my Face.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Come, my Lord, wou'd you confine a Woman of Honour? give her Liberty; wou'd you corrupt her? confine her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Tis true; were I a Wife to such a Man, I shou'd abuse him out o' Pride; and think my self not an ill but a great Woman, since to punish is a mark of Princely Dignity.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This I confess is the English Dialect; and when I talk of Governing Women, I talk of a thing not understood by our Nation. I admire how it came about, that we who are of all Nations, the most wise and free in other respects, shou'd be the only Slaves and Fools to Women.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh! you are the Wisest of all Nations, you know let Men do what they can, Women will do what they please; and whereas other Nations by their spyes and Governantes are at great toyle and charges to be Cuckolds, you have it for nothing.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Come Brother, do not dress me in a Fools Coat, nor hang spyes about me, like so many gingling Bells, to give notice of all my motions. I can count, and know that one and one, put shamefully together, are two lewd Fools, and not one happy pair, as ill Women reckon, and deceive themselves.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Sister, I believe you Virtuous, but I wou'd have you not only be Virtuous but thought so. And truly a Woman may be Virtuous, but is seldome
wise in Mens company. Her vain honour will put her on new Conquests. And Womens Conquests are pretty things; they often end like those of Highway Men, in a shameful Execution on their one Persons. And yet all the business of their lives is mustering up Forces. To day the Beauty Lyes ambush'd in undresses, the hair pin'd up in Papers, like Serpents coyl'd to fly on you with greater force; the Garments are loose and flowing as the Sea, to shew a Venus is there. To morrow she's as regularly fortified as a Low Country Town, and oft a party of Charming looks are sent abroad to put all Spectators under a contribution.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Your Wife must not dress?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why shou'd she? I think Womens Poynts and Embroyderies, but so many Billet-doux in Needle work.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: She must not go abroad or see a play.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, She may go to Plays, provided she'l see Plays and not Fools, it may be enter into Conversation with 'em, and instead of getting Wit from the Plays, get folly from the Fops; and so her Wit being spoyl'd in her Youth, shall like a Clock set wrong in the Morning, go false all the day after. In short, no Wife or Sister of mine shall dabble in conversation with any Man; I hate a Slattern in her credit.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I' my conscience I think I hear Belguard and his Mistress quarrel in good earnest.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Let no Woman marry a Man o' your humour, but she that for her Crimes is condemn'd to Transportation. The Slave that in Virginia toyls to plant her Lord Tobacco, is not more miserable, than she that in your bosome Labours to plant a good opinion; both drudge for smoke. I scorn the slavery, nor will marry a King to encrease his Dominions, but to share 'em.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I offer you the entire Dominion o' my self; only desire you, not to aim at further conquests.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I shou'd be a fine Soveraign, where Jealousie, Pride, Rage, and such a sawcy Committee shall give me Laws; which they wou'd never do to a Prince they lov'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I think I've given convinceing Proofs of Love.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: When I offer'd, Madam, to take you for better and for worse; those are Heroical Complements. The form of Matrimony out-does Ovid for passionate expressions.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ay, my Lord, but that's none o' your Wit, and I wou'd not have a Man o' your parts, steal other Mens Phrases; so Your Lordships humble Servant.— Come away Child

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p:
Rare! they'r parted; once a Woman spoke truth. My Lord, your Servant. I've over heard your quarrel, and I honour you, you are the only Man in the Nation that understands himself. Lock up the Women till they'r musty, better they shou'd have a Hogo, than their Reputations. And their
Honours are not like their Smocks, whitened by lying abroad.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nor have their ador'd Faces the more esteem, for often appearing.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: pox on 'em, they varnish like Copper, and the Women are sensible of it, that's the reason they forge new faces every time they go abroad; and all the Arts of Paint and dress are suborn'd to give a Bastard beauty Title to Reign, because the Legitimate Face is fallen into contempt by familiarity. No more to be said, keep your ground like a Man of honour; and loose your Mistress like a Coxcomb.—

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: An't please your Honour, Mr. Hothead and Mr. Testimony, are return'd, as your Honour gave order.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That's well— come Mr. Testimony; here has been a mistake gave me a harsh opinion of you— I'm sorry for it.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Oh! My Lord, have a care of censuring Professors— for a Professor.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay, prethee don't profess too much. I am satisfied with thee.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Truly you would, if you knew of what a tender Spirit I am of. I was only deluded the other day into a Play-house, and truly it will be a burden to my Spirit whilst I live.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A lack a day, well I hope you'l be the more tender of my Sister, your trouble will not be long. I have engag'd her to a Gentleman, whom about this time I expect. What a clock is it?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Truly I do believe it is about Four, I cannot say it positively; for I wou'd not tell a Lye for the whole World.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is an excellent Fellow, if he be what he pretends. (knocking. Hark! some one at the Door— may be 'tis he— see—

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Did you send for me, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, Cousin, to reconcile my self to thee; I was in a mistake.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: I think you was, when you judg'd a Rascally Fanatick a better Man than I.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The contrary Cousin— I think thee so much the better Man, I keep thee to have an eye over him, because I don't know if he be a Knave.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Not know if a Fanatick be a Knave? You'r fit to sit in the House o' Peers I faith.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, thou art a very honest Fellow Cousin— let me have thy Company. But what are those Patches on thy Face, for Ornament?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: they are for Plaisters, but they are Ornaments. I have been in a Fanatick Coffee-House, and this is the Beauty they gave me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Twas to reward some honourable Names, thou gav'st 'em.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: I gave 'em no wrong names. I call'd 'em Rogues indeed, but that's their proper Name; and they all set their hands to it immediately, and subscribed themselves Rogues upon my Chops, the only true Narrative they ever writ.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thou art a mad Fellow— prethee go in.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well— who's at the Door?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: A lamentable Soul.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Beggar?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: A more sad Object; but I conceive he comes rather to rob than beg, for he comes Arm'd with a strong Bow and Arrows.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Bow and Arrows? what, is he a Tartar?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: A Bow and Arrows made of Ribons, Laces, and other idle Vanities, wherewith he intends to wound your Sister's heart.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! the canting Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Nay, why canting Coxcomb?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Be gone you senceless Ass; and bring in the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Nay, why senceless Ass? this is unseemly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He wont stir.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: I am no senceless Person— I ha' more sences than your self▪ I have a sence o' Vanity, and of the nothingness o' the things o' this World— and a sence o' Sin, and a sence o' the insinuating nature o' sin— I dare not bring this wanton frothy young Man to your Sister— for she is frothy also— and sin will get in at a little crany— and if sin once get in his head, he'l get in all his whole body. now your honour has not that sence o' these things. You ought to have that Your Honour is a senceless Person—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: — How Sirrah—?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: In a spiritual sence—.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: There's no getting this preaching Fellow away.— Cousin Hothead.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why do you let this canting Coxcomb plague me?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Why do you keep such a canting Coxcomb? let him plague you, Pox you, and Damn you, I don't care.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Oh! sad! oh! sad!

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Oh! shad! oh! Sot!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So, now I've brought 'em both upon me.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: He's always tuning his Nose, too high too low, like a Sowgelders Horn

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, Sir, if you please, tell me who's at my Door?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Forty One is coming in ding dong.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Into My Door? who's at my Door, I say?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Old Forty One, I'faith.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I cannot have an answer— Sirrah— who's at my Door?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Popery, I'm sure is coming in.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Into my Door? I ask you, who's at my Door?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Popery I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Roguery I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Popery I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Roguery I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Confound you both.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: And confound you both.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You Boy, is there any one at Door?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So, this Boy can answer, who is it?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Sir Courtly Nice, My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O! these Rogues, have they made him wait all this while? introduce him quickly. He comes most seasonably to rid me of my plague, now I'm very sick of it.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Courtly and the Page, bowing to one another.
sp.p: Dear Sir Courtly, my Servants did not tell me who you were, that I have ignorantly made you wait, I am a sham'd to see you.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your Lordships most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your very humble Servant Page— call my Sister.
sp.stage: goes to Salute Leo. Aunt steps first.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Madam your most—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Sir Courtly, your very humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! your Ladyships very humble Servant—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Now Madam, your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: An incomparable fine Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, Sir Courtly, now I've brought you thus far o' your way to my Sisters inclinations; I'le leave you to pursue the rest o' your journey by your self; you need no guide to Ladies hearts.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: No, Sir Countly commands all. If my Neice does not receive you, Sir Courtly, in all the obliging manner in the World, 'tis for want of experience and understanding merit— I'le assure you, Sir Courtly, I who have some little more judgment, have had a very particular value for you, Sir, from the first Minute I had the honour to see you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: A very particular—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: And if my Neice has not, it proceeds from her want of Years to know Desert. And indeed all Youth is indiscreet, I wou'd by no means advise a Gentleman of Merit, to marry any Person, that has not some Years and experience upon her—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She's setting up for her self I think. Aunt.—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Nephew—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pray leave the Lovers together.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Sir Courtly, your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: Madam, your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Pray, Neice, behave your self so to Sir Courtly, as at least to do me right; and by all your expressions and behaviour, he may know how very particular an honour I have for him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She has for him?—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Most particular.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pray Aunt in particular— come with me—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Very particular—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam— Madam—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Aunt—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Yes Nephew— Sir Courtly, I am exceeding unwilling to leave you to to the Conversation of a young Lady, whose Years I'm afraid will not afford her Wit enough to entertain so fine a Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam! Madam! Madam!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: But I'le return with all speed possible.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But you shall not, if I can help it—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: And so your very humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam! your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Now will I manage him, humour him— pretend to admire him— to draw him into love, laugh at him and revenge my self on him, for plaguing me.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Now, Madam, is the glorious opportunity come, which my Soul has long wish'd, to express how much I admire, adore—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! Sir Courtly—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Extravagantly adore!—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! Sir Courtly— I cannot receive all this.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, is there any thing on the Earth so charming?— I never saw any thing so fine as your Ladyship, since I was born.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Fye, Sir Courtly—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Never since I was born—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You'l kill me with blushing.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I speak my Soul— Heavens! what Divine Teeth there are?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Fye! fye! I shall never open my mouth more.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Then you'l undoe all the World. Oh! there's nothing so charming as admirable Teeth. If a Lady fastens upon my heart, it must be with her Teeth.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That's a pleasant Raillery— ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, I hope your Ladyship has a better opinion o' my good Manners— Railly a Lady o' your quality?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! you Wits, turn all things into ridicule.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Madam, I never was so serious since I was born; therefore I beseech your Ladyship have pitty upon me.— I swear and vow if you do not, I shall dye.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Dye! ha! ha! you Wits will be raillying.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Heavens, Madam! how shall I convince you, I am serious.?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Really, Sir Courtly, I shou'd be very sorry if you be serious.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Heavens! why so Madam?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Because 'tis pitty so fine a Gentleman shou'd lose all his Gallantry—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Now you frighten me, Madam. Is it impossible for me to attain the Glory of your inclinations?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: It will be impossible for me to keep the Glory of your inclinations, Sir Courtly; so I dare not venture on 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! as to that, Madam, I'le swear Eternal constancy, eternal services, and all those things.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You are not in your own power, Sir Courtly. You fine Gentlemen, like fine Countries, are desir'd and fought by all, and therefore in a perpetual War. If I shou'd place my heart in you, it wou'd not have a minutes quiet. A thousand Potent Beauties wou'd every day assault you, and you'd yield out o' Complaisance, your good Breeding wou'd undo me.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, this is extremity o' Gallantry; your Ladyship pushes things to a strange height.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I speak my Soul. Besides i've another humour, but that's a Foibless will ridicule me.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Nay i'le confess it. I am strangely curious— extravagantly curious— I nauseate a Perfume if it ever saluted any Nose but my one.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! fortunate! my own humour.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Nothing must come near me, that was ever once touch'd by another.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Not if you'd give a Hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: My own Phrase too, i've observ'd it in my self, i'me strangely fortunate— we shall be fond to an infinite degree.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: For that reason, your fine Gentlemen is my aversion, he's so tempted by all Ladies, so Complaisant to all Ladies, that to marry a fine Gentleman, is to accept the leavings of a Thousand Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam! you ha' met with the Creature you desire;— I never touch'd Woman since I was born.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That's pleasant, I believe you have ruin'd a thousand.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Not one upon my Soul.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam! there's not one Lady in a thousand I can Salute. I only touch the tip o' their ear with my Cheek.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Fy! fye!

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: Not one Lady in a Million, whose breath I can endure. But I cou'd not go into their Beds, if you'd give me a Thousand pound. I cou'd not come into the Ayr of any Bed in England but my own, or Your Ladyships, if you'd give me all the World.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: This is all Gallantry, Sir Courtly. You have been told this is my humour.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Is it really, Madam?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! above all things. I suffer nothing to come near my bed, but my Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Nor I, but my Gentleman. He has a delicate hand at making a Bed, he was my Page, I bred him up to it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: To making Beds?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, and I believe, he'l make a Bed with any Gentleman in England.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And my Woman has a great Talent.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Is it possible? Ladies commonly employ ordinary Chamber Maids— with filthy Aprons on, made by sluttish Women that spit as they— spin— foh!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Foh!

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your Ladyship will pardon me— my Linnen is all made in Holland, by neat Women that dip their Fingers in Rose-water, at my charge.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Delicate.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: And all wash'd there.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And so is mine at Hearlem.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: At Hearlem, I hold a constant correspondence with all the Eminent Washers there.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That's delicate, and agrees wonderfully with my humour.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! happy! we shall be fond to an infinite degree.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! foh! here's that beastly rude Clown Mr. Surly.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! foh! what shall we do with him?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: How now? how now? you two are intimate— heark you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! foh!

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Foh!

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Foh! what's this fohing at?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: No body Mr. Surly; only at present we are accosted with an ungrateful smell.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Yes, I smell an ungrateful smell, your Rogury. Madam, I employ'd this Fellow to speak for me, and i'le be hang'd if he be not false to me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: To speak for him? ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Ay, for him, Madam, ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Ay, for me Nickumpoop.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your humble Servant Sir, y' are very civil.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: So I am, that I do not execute thee for this theft upon the place; but thou plead'st thy Face, as Whores do their Bellys; 'tis big with Fool.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Very civil— Sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Sure, Madam, a Woman o' your sence, will not chuse him before me. He has more Land? not more improv'd Land. His Acres run up to one great Weed, I mean himself; and there it Blossoms in Periwigs and Ribons. Oh! but he has a finer Person! that's a cheat; a false Creed impos'd on you, by a General Council of Taylors, Milleners and Sempstresses; let my hat expound his Face, and youl see what a peice o' simple stuff it is.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Horrid! he has put his beastly Hat upon my Head— pray Sir do me the favour to remove it, or I shall grow very sick—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Sick? I hope thou wilt eat my Hat. Now, Madam, you see what a cheat he is, and whether he deserves any more favours, then to be decently hang'd with the rest of his Brothers.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: My Brothers hang'd, Mr. Surly?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I mean the Pictures in the Hangings, for they and thou are all but Needle-work; and thou would'st serve for a peice o' Tapstery, but for a Husband, Lord, ha' Mercy on thee.

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: Your Servant, Mr. Surly. You are a very well bred Gentleman, Sir, and pay great Veneration to a Lady o' Quality, and your Mistress— ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: His Mistress? ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Let's railly him to death, Madam— ha! ha!—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Railly? does the ridiculous Figure pretend to laugh at any thing?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Dee' hear, Madam?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Sir Courtly, you are a Martyr to good manners, and suffer out o' respect to me, more than is fit for a Man to bear.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: He a Man? I ha' seen a Butler make a better thing out of a Diaper Napkin.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your most obliged humble Servant— Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Sir Courtly, I'le withdraw, that you may do your self Justice— and be kick'd—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your Ladyships most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I'le no longer protect such a Coxcomb— as your self.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your very humble Servant, Madam; I'le push his Soul out presently.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! don't do him that favour, Sir, only correct him.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Well, Madam, what your Ladyship pleases.—
Your Ladyships very humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Mr. Surly,
sp.p: I have receiv'd some favours from you, Sir, and I desire the Honour of your Company, Sir, to Morrow morning at Barn-Elms, Sir,— please to name your Weapon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: A Squirt.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: A Squirt?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Ay, for that will go to thy heart, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I shall kiss your hands.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Kiss my Breech.—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Beast, Clown, Fool, Rascal. Pox take him— what shall I do with him? it goes against my stomach horribly to fight such a Beast. If his filthy Sword shou'd touch me, 'twou'd make me as sick as a Dog.
sp.stage: Scene a Garden. Enter Cr. and Leonora.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ha! ha! I'le secure the Coxcomb— I'le get him confin'd upon the Guard, among Tobacco takers and that will confine him to his Bed and Bagnio's for one Month.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: That will do rarely. About this time I expect Mr. Farewel, I ha sent for your Brother to introduce him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My Brother?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Your Brother I say, to shew my skill. Retire, and stay conceal'd in the Garden. Here your Brother comes.
Now for lies and nonsence to entertain this jealous Brother till the Lover comes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir Thomas your Servant, what's your will with me?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Talk— I love talk— begin.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Very pithy.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: In what circumstance are we?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Circumstance?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Ay, what call you this, where we are?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Garden.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: A Garden? i've seen in the Indies a Melon as big.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: As all this Garden?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Bigger.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well lyed of a Mad-man. (aside.) Are all your Fruit so large?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: All.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your Nutmegs and Pepper are not.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Your History is erronious. We have Nutmegs as big as small Fly-boats, I have sail'd a hundred Leagues in a Nutmeg.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well lyed.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Our Oysters have wonderful conferrence.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Circumference I suppose you mean.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Y' ave nick'd it. Three of 'em block up a Harbour. 'Tis our way of Mortification.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Fortification.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: You are in the right— Pox on't I have been so long abroad, I have almost forgot my Mother tongue.
Well— when will this Lover come? 'tis near the hour, and delicately dark.
Murder! murder! murder!

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: That's he! he's come! (aside.) murder cryed out.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And at my Coach-house Door?
Oh! Cowardly Rogues! Four upon one.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: A Gentleman assassinated?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Open the Door.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Call some o' the Servants to assist a Gentleman, set upon at my Coach-House Door.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Ay— quick— quick—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How, Sir Thomas? will you venture among 'em?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Dee' think I wont? a Gentleman and not fight?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I must not suffer it, you may be hurt.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: No Sir, I'le fight like a Gentleman; I'le come by no hurt I'le warrant you.— Come quick— quick— open the Door—
Now Sound a Trumpet, Tivy— tivy— tan tan— tivy— Tone,— Pox on't 'tis a Horn— I don't know a Horn, I ha' forgot every thing belongs to a Gentleman.— among 'em— helter skelter—
sp.stage: (Exit Bel. Cr. and Ser. mean while Farewel steals into the Garden.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I' my conscience this is Cracks design to let in Mr. Farewel.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Dear Madam you are in the right.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Mr. Farewel? I know your voice—

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, I adore you for this bounty.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And I shou'd blush for it.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Why so, Madam?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Shou'd a Woman admit a Lover by night at a Back-Door into the same house wher she lyes, and converse privately with him before Marriage.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Your Brother admitted me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed, you may thank him for the favour, I thought your sufferings deserv'd pity, and my Brother wou'd let me shew it, no other way.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: A thousand Blessings on you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I doubt not but my honour is very safe in your keeping, I wish your Person, were as secure in mine.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I am glad o' the danger, since tis some assurance o' my Love.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Your Friend Mr. Crack plays his part very well, and I doubt not but he will secure us here, and conveigh us hence, but then other dangers will follow you.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: What are those, Madam?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: The danger of marrying without a Fortune, my Ten thousand pound is at my Brothers dispose.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I am glad of that too, Madam, 'twill shew my love is not mercenary.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: The danger of being laught at by the Wits, for marrying at all.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Oh! let the Wits keep the Jilting rotten Wenches, and leave the sweet Virtuous Ladies to us marrying Fools, I can be as well pleas'd to keep a fine Wife to my self, as they can be to maintain five Wenches for all the Town.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Nay, your keeping Men, Keepers like have commonly but the Offals for their Slave. Well the Evening Ayr will be unwholsome to you, if you stay longer in it, you'l be in danger of Thunder and Lightning presently, I mean my Brother— he comes— follow me—

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What Cowardly Rogues were these? they ran upon our first sallying.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: They had a reason, you'r a Lyon.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I us'd to kill Lyons and Tygers in the Indies, as you do Hares and Conyes here. I kept a Tyger Warren, I kill'd a brace every morning to get me a stomack.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It was a good one sure, you offer'd dear for it. Well I hope you ha' got no hurt?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Yes, something very sharp, went quite through my stomack.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How? through your stomack? then you cannot live.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Yes, if you noint it presently with a good dish o' Jelly-broth, and Tent it with a bone o' Roast-beef.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Is that the wound? it shall be heal'd presently.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Presently, for my stomack is Captious.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It shall be done. Go to my Aunt and desire her to order Sir Thomas his Supper—

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: She's not very well, my Lord, and gone to bed.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then let the Steward do it. Sir Thomas I am going out and shall stay late. Pray command my house— good Night to you—

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir— you keep a Woman?— now to the Lovers— where are they?—
sp.stage: Enter Farewel, Leo. and her Woman.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Here! here! thou Divine Fellow.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: So, so, kiss! kiss! kiss!—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Before Marriage?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Ay, for fear you shou'd not kiss after marriage— well the house is our own, and the Night our own— your Aunt's gone to bed, and your Brother abroad, we'l Tory— rory, and 'tis— a fine Night, we'l Revel in the Garden— Slaves go bring my Supper— quick— quick—
sp.stage: Ex. Slaves— and enter with Dishes: Farewel, Leo. and Crack sit down.
sp.p: Now a Song and Dance o' your own fashion— but shut the Garden. Gates— and look to 'em well, for I'le be private in my pleasures—
— So— now to my Chamber— well— there is no publick Officer like your Pimp—.

l.hi: Pimps manage the great business o' the Nation.
That is— the Heavenly work o' propagation.

div.head: ACT. V.
div.stage: Scene Cracks Chamber. Enter Farewel and Crack.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: OH! thou Divine Fellow, what joys hast thou procured me?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What joys?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: All that Innocence cou'd afford.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Innocence? that's insipid stuff.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: No Mr. Crack, there's difference between the Mannah that came, from Heaven, and that out of 'Pothecaries Shops; a touch of Leonora's hand like Mannah from Heaven has all that Man can fancy. Here she comes.
This, Madam, is bountiful after an Evenings Conversation, to afford me a Morning too.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: We shou'd be charitable to Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I am a Prisoner, but such a happy one, as a King is when Lodg'd in a Royal Tower, to prepare for his Coronation. My hour of Coronation draws near, I want only the Church Ceremony and the Oath.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Madam, how dirst you venture hither, by day light?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My Aunt, and Brother, are both gone abroad, and won't come home till Noon. So all those hours are mine, and now Mr. Crack to requite your Musick I ha' brought some o' mine to entertain you.
sp.stage: A Song— And enter a Woman.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Oh! Madam— undone— your Brother.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: How? how?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Just coming up stairs, to visit— you Sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Pox of his civility. Hide, Sir Hide. And do you Women shreike!— shreike! and cry out murder.
sp.stage: Cr. throws himself on the ground and scrambles in distracted postures after the Women. They shreike—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So, here's my Sister got into the Madmans Room; and has put him into a frantick fit. Oh! the insatiable curiosity o' Women.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: You Whores!— you bewitching Whores, do you come to bewitch me? I'le fetch blood from you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why wou'd you offer to come hither, Sister?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What are you, Sir, the King of Bantam?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No Sir, no.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Oh! the Mogul.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nor the Mogul.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What do you then with all these Concubines?— Oh! I know you now, you'r a fine man, you have put me into brave circumstances. Did not I desire you to let me see no Women? and here, you keep a company o'rambling Whores in your house, that have put me into the circumstances o' distraction. I was a top o' the Staircase taking a prospect o' the Cape of Good-Hope, and these Flyboats came sayling under my Nose. What do me I? but leap down to break their Necks? and ha' broke my own I think. I am certain, I have broke something, but what I don't know. Pray take me up, and look over my bones, see if none be missing; if they be, Bone for Bone will be demanded.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Poor creature! who's there?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Who's there? will you trust me to your servants! so if a Leg or an Arm of mine be broke, they'l leave it behind e'm, and I shall loose it. I expect all my Limbs and Bones from you, as you received 'em. So— come and take account of 'em.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I will— I will—

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Oh! have a care— Oh!—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Alas! I fear he's hurt; your foolish curiosity ha's done this? did you not gape enough upon him before?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Oh! gently! gently!— so— so—

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Oh! this pleasant Rogue! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Tis an excellent fellow. As soon as we hear my Brother is returning, slip into that passage, 'twill lead you to Crak's Bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: How now Gentlewoman? a man wi' you? Nephew— Nephew— Nephew.—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Begone— begone— through that Entry.
sp.stage: Ex. Fa. at one Door, at another Enter Bellguard.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Our family's dishonour'd, dishonour'd— here was a fellow, a handsome young fellow wi' my Neice. Oh! my flesh! my flesh.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Wi' me?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Will you deny it Confidence?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Who's there? Hothead, Testimony, all of you come hither.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: What's your honours pleasure?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: To cut all your throats, you are all Bauds and Villains.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Leave me out o' the number you had best.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I will not Sir, For here was a young fellow wi' my Sister;

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My Aunt's whimsy and jealousie.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: I cou'd tread you under my feet.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Which way went he?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Into that passage: He cannot be got further, then Sir Thomas Calicoes Bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Lock all the doors, Arm and beset Sir Thomas Calicoes lodgings.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: This will prove such another wise business as the Picture.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold your peace— get you into that room wi' my Aunt. Aunt pray look to her.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: I'le keep her, I warrant her— come in gentlewoman.— you are a fine gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! my heart trembles— Heaven inspire Crack.
sp.stage: Ex. Aunt and Leonora. Scene changes to another Room.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Oh! cursed fortune.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Well don't trouble your self. I'le bring you off safe.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Not trouble my self, when Leonora's honour is in danger? she'l be the jest of every prating Fop, and malitious beauty.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Her honour shall be safe too. This blustering— Brother shall entertain you.—

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: With a Blunderbuss?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Ay, full o' Claret. Away— away— he comes?
sp.stage: Ex. Fa. and Enter Bellguard, Hothead, Testimony, and the Servants arm'd.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: How? the High and glorious Emperour o' Siam with all his guards? Thou most invincible Paducco, Farucco,— nelmocadin— bobbekin— bow—— wow— ww— why dost thou seek to destroy us English, seated on thy Dominions by thy own Letters Patents?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pish!— take him away.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Take away our Priviledges? then this goes to my heart.
sp.stage: Draws his Dager, and pretends to stab himself.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold, hold— Sir Thomas— Sir Thomas, no hurt is ment to you.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Most Great and Glorious Emperour, I humbly thank, and do humbly Implore thee; that thou wou'dst command thy Invincible guards, to lay down their arms, and put us out of our frights, and we'l submit our persons to thee. This is some Interlopers work.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Pox o' this impertinent mad— coxcombe? Lay down your weapons,
may be if we humour him, he may come to his sences, and give us leave to search the rooms.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: My Lord Bellguard, your most humble servant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He's come to himself; that's well. Sir Thomas your servant, how do you?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: A little discompos'd, something has frightned me, and put me into the circumstance of a sweat.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'me sorry for that. Shall I beg leave, to search your rooms for a theif that's got in?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Pardon's beg'd; search must not be made; for I have a friend there, you must not see. Wou'd you and your friend were hanged.
A very honest Gentleman, but very much addicted to marriage. 'Tis he that I told you, is to marry my Indian Fubs of a Sister— Mr Farewel.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Mr. Farewel?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Ay, hearing of my arrival, and what circumstance I was in; hover'd all this morning about the house to get a sight o' me; but car'd not to come in, for it seems there is enmity between you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis True, and I wonder how he got in without my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I made him come in. I was throwing my legs about in the Hall, and the door being open, our eyes knock'd immediately, and gave remembrance such a bang, that we ran full speed into the circumstances of embracing?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And pray who saw this?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Who saw? what care I who saw? I care not if the whole Town saw, I'm not asham'd of owning Mr. Farewel.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No Sir, but I mean which of my family saw? that I may thank 'm for their care.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What do I care for your family? if I may not bring a friend into your family, a fart for your family.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay be not angry Sir Thomas, your friend's welcome.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I doubt it not, for I have found you a very civil person. And now recollection is active, I fancy he's the man you take for a theif. Tis so— ha! ha!— excuse me— ha! ha!— leave is implord— ha! ha!— brot'her Farewel.
Brother.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Come out, and participate o' laughter.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So, now have I play'd the fool again, vex'd my self, and wrong'd my Sister with my impertinent jealousies.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Come brother— ha! ha! laugh— but first salute.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
My Lord, I believe you wonder to see me here, and you may; I call my self Bastard, and renounce the blood o' my family, by coming under your roof with any design, but to prejudice you, which at present I must acknowledge to my shame is not my intention. I visit my friend here for his
own sake, and the sake of a great Beauty, which you shall not hinder me of, My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I will not Mr. Farewel, I scorn those effeminate revenges. If I hurt any Man it shall be with my Sword.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Your Sword, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Hold? hold.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay any where but here Mr. Farewel, my House is your Sanctuary, and here to offer you violence, wou'd prejudice my self.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: What a quarrelling's here? i'my conscience I believe, my Lord, 'tis because you think he came to steal me, I being under whimsical circumstances, for I remember you call'd him a Thief. Look you, My Lord don't fear me, I won't be stole— I know when I'm well— Brother I'm very well provided for, I want nothing but my Wits; and what do they signifie? if a Man lives like a Gentleman, no matter whether he has Wit or no—

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Well, my Lord, though I have the misfortune to be your Enemy, I am none to good manners; I am sorry I ha' given your house this trouble, and the more because my Friend receives such generous usage in it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nor am I an Enemy to Love, and the fair Sex. If the Lady you come for loves you, for her sake I wish you success.—

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Now my Lord you vanquish me.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: He's a brave Man— Faith.—

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I fancy we shall live to be better Friends, at present I'le take my leave,— my Lord your Servant.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Brother I must see you down stairs. This was a Master-peice. ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now I am cool again. What a flame had your negligence put me into. Here release my Sister, I'm asham'd to see her—

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Sirrah! Sirrah! you did this to make me suspected.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Ay— ay, I must be abus'd, because I'm a Protestant.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: A Protestant? a Dog. But with such Names the Rogues divide the Rabble, and make the Nation go like the Devil, upon Cloven Feet.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold your prating, and by your future care make amends for your past negligence; your trouble shall not be long, within this Eight and forty hours I'le marry her, or send her into the Country.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Well— well— I'le look to her, for the Honour of my Family, not your huffing.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: I to discharge a Conscience—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: So— Sir—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Sister—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Do you run from me? is that the reparation you make for the intolerable wrongs you have done me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Well, I have wrong'd you, I'm sorry for it, and beg your Pardon—
I must be gone— about business— your business— to fetch Sir Courtly Nice. your Servant, Sister.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! your Servant Sir— ha! ha!— he runs — I may chance Sir to run as nimbly from you, if Cracks Wit do not fail him— here he comes—
Thou admirable Fellow, what hast thou done with Mr. Farewel?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: He's in the Street staying for you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Staying for me? and can'st thou conveigh me to him?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Dee' question it? put on a Vizard and something over your Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Sweet Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Nay, nay be gone.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Delicate Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Nay, nay he stays for you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Incomparable Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Pshaw! put on your Vizard.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Most excellent Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Oones! put on your Vizard.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I will— I will— ha! ha! toll— loll— derol—
sp.stage: Cr. goes out, and as Leo. is going out singing and danceing, She's met by Bell. and Sir Co.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! Sister your tune's alter'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam! I'm happy to find your Ladyship, in so gay a humour.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You'l not find it so—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir Courtly I'le betray her to you. I left her in Tears upon an unhappy occasion, and at parting told her I wou'd bring you. Now you are come, I find her in joy. Nothing else cou'd cause the change.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! fortunate.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! Fop!—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now improve your interest, and let us see how great a Master you are in Courtship, by your dextrous dispatch. I leave you together—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: And upon my Soul I will. Oh! Madam, am I so Fortunate, so Glorious, to be well in your fine inclinations?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! fye, Sir Courtly— if I had any such guilt upon me, do you think I wou'd confess?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: You do confess, Madam— your fine Eyes, and your languishing Ayr, and your charming Blushes, and all those things—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I hope I carry no such false things about me; for if they say any such thing they infinitely wrong me.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! now you are cruel, Madam; you kill me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Can you hope for my heart Sir Courtly, till I've some assurance o' yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: What assurance wou'd your Ladyship have?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
All manner— he that pretends to my heart— must sigh, and wait,
and watch— and pant— and fight, and write— and kill himself.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: All this I ha' done, Madam, and Ten thousand things more. Drove by your Windows, a thousand times a day, sought you at the Parks and the Plays. Was a constant faithful Attendant at all Tragedys— for I presum'd your Ladyship nauseates Comedys—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! Foh!—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: They are so ill— bred— and sawcy with Quality, and always cram'd with our odious Sex— that have not always the most inviting smell— Madam, you'l Pardon me— Now at Tragedies, the House is all lin'd with Beauty, and then a Gentleman may endure it. And I have gone, found not your Ladyship there, drove home, kill'd my self with sigthing, and then writ a Song.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! Heavens! Sir Courtly, did you ever write a Song upon me?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Above a thousand.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! there's nothing charms me like a Song—
For Heavens sake— the Song!— the Song—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I've above forty here in a sweet Bag, I'le shew you the first I made upon Your Ladiship. 'Tis thought to be a pretty Foolish soft Song, most Ladies are very kind to it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! Sir Courtly—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.l: Which you did wi' such art;

sp.speaker: Leo
sp.p: Oh! fine! oh! fine!

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: That stop Thief, Madam, is pretty Novel.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! delicate! I'm charm'd! I'm lost!— fye what have I said—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: What makes me the happyest of Creatures.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I only railly— I renounce all—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Not for the World—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Away— the Song again— the Song— I'le hear nothing but the Song. Is there no tune to it?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: One of my own composing.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That accomplishment to? Heavens! how fine a Gentleman is this?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, how prou'd you make me?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! dear, how I betray my self? foolish Creature— no more— no more— the Tune, the tune.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I always humour my words with my Ayr. So I make the Voice shake at the last Line, in imitation of a Man that runs after a Thief. Sto— ho— ho— hop— Thief—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! delicate! cannot I learn it? sto— ho— ho— ha! ha! ha!
sp.stage: (imitates his Foolish singing and falls into a laugh.)

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Dear Madam, what makes your Ladyship laugh?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: At a Coxcomb, that thought to win me with a Foolish Song, this puts it into my head.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Foolish! there are abundance of those Foolish Fellows, and does the Song please your Ladyship?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Infinitely, I did not think you had been so fine a Poet.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Poetry, Madam, is my great foible, and when I see a fine Woman I cannot command my foible.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: How? dee' make Songs upon other Ladies? unfortunate I've given my heart to aninconstant Man—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam,— only Gallantry.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I'm abus'd— unfortunate—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, you take it wrong—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I'm abus'd.—

sp.speaker: Sir. Co.
sp.p: Oh! Heavens!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: But the Songs very fine!— sto— ho— ho— ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Pleasant Creature.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Coxcomb.—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: We shall be infinitely fond— a pretty Glass, this Madam

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: So he's making an assignation with his own foolish Face, I'le leave him to Court that and steal away.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Sto— ho— ho— hop—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Singing, Sir Courtly?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: At your Service, Madam. Well, Madam, you have said so many fine things to me, that I assure my self of your heart, and now I am resolv'd to push this opportunity, to an extremity o' happyness.
sp.stage: (Sir Courtly looks in the Glass while he speaks.)

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! fortunate! this to me? I did make him some advances to day I confess, and have they had this success? my heart pants: I am surpris'd with infinite joy, and am not able to answer—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I must be happy, and so upon my— the Lady gone—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Sir Courtly you put me in great confusion—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: The Lady's consent is very considerable— she governs her Neice, and under her conduct may make me happy, with a reserve to Modesty. (aside.) Well, Madam, shall I have your consent to my happyness, my glory?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! dear Sir! is it possible to answer you so soon?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: So soon, Madam? you know my passion has been long.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Is it possible? I swear I never heard of it before.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: That's strange; wou'd not my Lord, your Nephew acquaint you?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: He never said one word of it to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: That's amazing.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: I find my Nephew has been false to me. It seems 'tis me the Gentleman loves, and my Nephew wou'd defrau'd me of him, for his Sister— here's fine doings.—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I swear I thought your Ladyship had known, and granted your consent— you said so many fine things—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: I said no more,— Sir Courtly, then what were the result o' my thoughts, upon the contemplation of your great desert—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your Ladyships most humble Servant— then I hope, Madam, since my passion has been long, though you knew not of it, you will not deferr my hapyness— 'tis in your power I'm certain, no Person controuls you—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Controuls me? that's pleasant— no Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: She says true— she can bring her Neice— (aside.) I beseech you, Madam, take pity of a suffering Lover.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, shou'd I consent so soon, 'twou'd be against all Forms.—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: I would not for the World offend against any Forms. No Man living more studyes, and adores all manner of Forms— but my passion has been long.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: I know not what to say, Sir, indeed I must not.—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Pardon me!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh! Pardon me!

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! Madam!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: You confound me, Sir:

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: You distract me, Madam. It must be.—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Well, Sir I yield, but with an extremity o' blushing.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your most obliged humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: My severe temper wou'd never ha' been wrought on so soon, but by so fine a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: And to revenge my self on my Nephew, for his false play.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Well, Madam, we'l in my Coach to the next Church presently.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: 'Tis very hard to resist you, Sir Courtly. If you please I will first put on a Disguise; for I desire it may be manag'd with all secrecy, till the Ceremony of Marriage be over.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: With all my Soul; for I infinitely love a secret Intrigue, especially when every body knows of it.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Least my Nephew light on us, and prevent it.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: He's for the Match.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: He's very false.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Is it not apparent, when he conceal'd the whole matter from me, least I shou'd promote it?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: That's unanswreable, I'm amaz'd at it. Well, Madam, I shall not fail of being happy?—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Immediately, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: And you think you have power?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Power? that's pleasant.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: So— so— she'l bring or send her— (aside.) Well, Madam, Your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Your very blushing Servant—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your humble— sto— ho— ho— hop— Thief—

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: An humble Thief indeed, steal an old Woman?—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: This was a pleasure I cou'd not ha' thought of. Now to our Affair.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Come— on with your Vizard.
sp.stage: Scene changes to the Hall. Enter at one Door, Hothead and Testimony, at another Crack.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Barbarity! falsehood! treachery! murder

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Did not I stipulate upon the surrendry of my self to this House, to be kept from Women? and I am devour'd with e'm; here's come into my Chamber, a hot burnt Whore, with a black crust upon her face— here she is, Avant.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: You damn'd Whore, how came you into this house? and what are you? I'le see your face.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Then I'le see your braines, I swear by Gogmagog, and all the seven damnable Sinnes.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Oh! sad! oh! sad

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Shew me the face of a Woman? I had rather see forty full moons.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Stand off Impertinence; I will see her face.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Murder! murder! call my Lord— Lord, Lord— murder— murder! Lord— Lord— Lord.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Hold your bauling, I'le let her go.— For now I think on't, If my Lord shou'd find this Whore here when he gave such strickt orders, we shou'd let no body out, or in, he'l make more noise than this mad fool— so let us kick her out o' Doors, and say nothing.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Hold, let us not use violence to her— she's a great temptation to me. (aside) I'le reprove the idle Woman, it may be, I may gain upon her.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Gain a Clap Sirrah! for this is some of the footmens Whores, pick'd up in the dark. Get you out you Whore.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: No violence pray. She's a great snare to me. (aside.) woman get you out woman— and dee hear?— I'le follow you, and we'l drink a bottle.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Do old godly knave, and thou shalt be welcome.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: I come! I come! (aside) get you out woman.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Get you out— you Whore.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Good morrow— up so early?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: What's the whimsy now?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Am not I i' Bed?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: In Bed?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Poor soul, poor soul—

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: I am not i' faith. Then I walk in my sleep: I was fast a sleep just now, and dream't I saw women, and Vizards, and all that Trash; and the fright put me in a Feaver. I burn; prethee give me a mouth full of sweet ayr.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Prethee take a belly full and be damn'd. A fine time on't I have; with Whores, and Fools, and mad Men, and Fanatiques.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: So, now I'le steal after her; for I find in me a very great uproar.
sp.stage: Scene changes to Violante's house. Enter Farewel— Leonora vizarded, Testimony.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Come in, come in honest old Fornicator, though the girle be mine, when I have had my collation, if she'l consent, faith, thou shalt have a bit; I love a Wenching Rogue i' my heart.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Oh! dear Sir, your very humble servant, and truly I am a kind of a wag. I love a pretty bit sometimes.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: And I love thee the better for it, and this is a pretty bit, thou shalt see her

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Oh! dear! undone! undone!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Nay, nay Mr. Testimony won't you be as good as your word? shan't we have a Bottle?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, don't discover me to my Lord, and you shall not only have my prayers, but the prayers of all the sober party for you all days o' my life.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: So, he runs from Whoring to Praying.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Are not you a Rogue Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: I know I shall be called Rogue, by the Popish party— they will rejoyce at my fall, but I hope my fall will be sanctified unto me for my better Upstanding.—

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Among the Wenches— Sirrah— come, Sirrah, you shall stay till my Lord comes, for his mortification, as well as yours.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Oh! my flesh, it has undone me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: My dear.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My dear.—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Excellent Crack; for this great peice o' service, I'le ha' thee knighted under a petticote. Well we must send for my Lord, to laugh at him.

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Oh! dear! I tremble!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Who's there? well my Lord, I desire to speak with him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Pray let him bring Sir Courtly Nice, and his bride with him; be sure you say nothing o' me.—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Are you a Bride yet?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Get in, and let my Chaplain make you one.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Come Mr. Testimony. Mr. Crack, bring him.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: How now you Rogue? what's your business?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: Oh! my reproach will be great.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Mr. Surly.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Well, what now?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Now, you shall be my Husband.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Your Jack, to turn and roast you for another, whilst I ha' no share in you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: According to the share I have in you: You men wou'd feign engross all manner o' Sinnes, by the pretended Prerogative o' your Sex; well if iniquity be your Estate, when you ha' married me, I'le put in for my thirds.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I doubt it not; within this week, I shall see in a Fop's hand, a Billet Doux, that is a Ticket to let him into your Play-house.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Prethee leave of this doged humour.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I ha' none; fawning is a Dogs humour.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Nay but Sullenness; it taxes thy Estate, that thou art never the better for it; tis a french Estate.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Ay, but to lick a fool's shoe, is a Spaniels Estate.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Prethee dress like a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: So I do,; but I wou'd not dress like a Gentleboy, lag at my years among those Children, to play with their Toys; be always followed up like a love letter, with a superscription, these to the next pretty girle.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: There's no altering thee— go in a while.
sp.stage: Ex. Surly. Enter Lord Belguard, Sir Courtly, Aunt vizarded.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: My Lord, your humble servant. I invited you hither, to reconcile you to your Sister, she's weary of your Government, and has dispos'd of herself.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, but according to my own desires, that now I suppose you will acknowledge the good effects of my Government;— Sister salute your friend.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Do you take that for your Sister? then I'le shew you the good effects of your Government. Open the Door.
sp.stage: The Scene is drawn, and Farewel, Leonora, a Parson, Crack, Testimony, appear.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Sister there? call my servants.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Nay then call mine, the great Mogul, and the King o' Bantam, I'le pepper you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then you were the Pimp were you— Sirrah— I may chance begin with you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: How? i' my house and presence? touch him if you dare.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'm made an Ass on.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: Not far from that circumstance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You Rascal—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Again?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: But what the Devil am I made? what have I got?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Even my stale Aunt.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Sawcy huzzy.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: The Aunt? what have you put upon me, Madam?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: What have I put upon you, Sir, more than your self desir'd? Did not you declare you have long had a passion for me?

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: A Passion for you? Comical! that's probable! Rot me if ever I had a Passion for you in my Life. I meant all to your Neice; a Passion for an old Woman?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Ill-bred Fop.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Very fine—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Now, my Lord, what say you of your fine Cotqueen art of Conserving Woman? will she keep if not candied with Virtue? here is a peice o' dryed Sweet-meat, you see cou'd not keep; and proves by her example, that the Hufls of either Sex, when they are boldly attacqued in private, soonest deliver their Weapons.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: This is all ill manners.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ay, but here's an old Cat will suffer no Vermin to come into the House; but then he has a Liquorish tooth, and loves to have a sweet bit for himself; he wou'd fain ha' pick'd up your Sister for a Wench.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Test.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed my Lord; I will not tell a lye for the whole World.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh! Villain— well Sirrah— I'le leave you to my Cousin Hot-heads correction.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: But your faults my Lord I'le take into my correction, and give my self to Mr. Surly—! Mr. Surly.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Well—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: To Surly?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Ay, now Nico thy quarrel and mine is at an end, Ile let thee be an Ass forty years longer.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: You are a rude fellow and you are all ill— bred— and I'le revenge my self on you all, as far as my Sword and my Wit can go—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Wit— ha! ha—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: — Very fine manners this— my Coach— Madam, you may follow your own occasions — I have none with an Old Woman.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: You are a Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Your Servant— my Coach—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Must I lose you Sir Courtly— stop Theif— stop Theif—

sp.speaker: Sir Co.
sp.p: Oh! your Servant— my Coach you Dogs—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Come my Lord, I see Patience in your Face, all may be well yet.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: How! Jilting already?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Promise I shall enjoy all and singular the Priviledges, Liberties, and immunities of an English Wife.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: All.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: That is to say, Ramble, Rant, Game, Dress, Visit, Prate, Ogle, Kiss— and—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold— hold— whether the Devil is she running: Kiss, kiss— and— stop for Heavens sake.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Kiss, and before your Face; is it not the Prerogative of an English Wife? Surly, I owe thee a reward for Service, kiss me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That's not to be borne.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Surly, I am thy Wife.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold— hold— for Heavens sake— do not use me thus?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Then do not Rebel but practise obediently, the postures of an English Husband, before you are Listed; Poise your Hat, draw your left Leg backward, bow with your Body, and look like an Ass, whilest I kiss like a— Wife — Surly kiss me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: — If he does—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: With all my Heart. If I kiss thee, let the Devil Marry thee.
sp.stage: (he offers to kiss her, and she gives him a box o'th' Ear.)

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And the Devil kiss thee, cou'dst thou think any Woman wou'd suffer thy face to come near her, but some Dairy Milk, to curdle her Milk?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Hoh! hoh! What a society o' Gotam's are here, to laugh at Man for missing a Woman? had I Married her, as my Lord Wise-acre intends to do, I had deserv'd to ha' been laught at, for a Coxcomb, and a Cuckold, as he will be in few Days.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: Ay, you are all Whores, Pox on you, all Whores.
sp.stage: Enter Hothead and all the Servants.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Did you send for us?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, do you see where my Sister is?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: By what witch craft was this?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Do not you remember a Vizard you turn'd out o' Doors?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Was it you?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Even the same.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Then you deserve to be turn'd out o' Doors again.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But what do you deserve Sir? that not only turn'd my Sister out o' Doors— but let Mr. Testimony— pick her up for a Wench.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Oh! Dog— oh! Rogue—

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.p: I am no Rogue— a Man may fall, and be Godly in the main — I am satisfied in my Spirit, I am a Godly Man—

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: — Here's a Rogue— Sirrah— Sirrah—

sp.speaker: Tes.
sp.p: Persecution— Persecution — Papist— do— kick the Godly, kick the Protestants out o' Kingdom— do Papist— I see what you wou'd be at—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So Cousin now I have done with spyes— you may follow your own business, if you have any—

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.p: Business? yes I have business, and will have business as long as there is a Fanatick in the Kingdom, and so farewell—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am now convinced, Vertue a Womans only guard. If she be base Metal, to think by Chimistry, to turn her into Gold,

l.hi: Is a vain dream of what we never see,
And I'le proclaim to all— It cannot be.

div.head: A SONG to be Sung in Dialogue between a Man and a Woman in the Third Act, to Sir Courtly Nice, at his first appearance.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: OH! be kind, my Dear, be kind,
Whilst our Loves and we are Young.
We shall find, we shall find
Time will change the Face or Mind;
Oh! be kind, my Dear, be kind.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: No, I Love, and fear to loose you,
When I've yielded you my Crown
No, I Love, and fear to loose you

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: If you can Charme with the Pain
Of Love, then what can you do with the Joy?

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: I fear to yield, but cannot deny.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: If you do not I shall die.

sp.speaker: Chorus together.
sp.l: Then come to Joy— come to Joy,
Better Love than we shou'd die.
Come to Joy, come to Joy.

div.head: A Dialogue Sung between an Indian Man and Woman, in the Fourth Act, to Farewel, Violante, Crack. Being an imitation of a Song, Sung by some Natives of India, before the late King.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: THou lovely Indian Sea of Charms,
Might I be so, blest to dive

l.hi: With a Jimminy, Gomminy, whee-whee, whee.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: I wou'd if you'd be true,
And throw me of with a Shooh-shooh, shooh.

l.hi: And a migotty, magotty, migotty, magotty,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: No, no, my other Females all
To thy Charmes shall prostrate fall,
As every kind of Elephant does
And thou alone shall have from me

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.l: The great Jaw-waw that Rules our Land,

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Thou alone shalt have from me

l.hi: Whee, whee, whee, whee, whee, whee.
